 The burakumin are a group of Japanese people who have suffered the most injustices . They have suffered from injustice in the country's most recent history .

 Shinto is based on the two major religious traditions in Japan, Shinto and Buddhism . Those practices are based on Shinto .
 Shintoists worship many gods, called kami, that are found in mountains, rivers, rocks, trees, and other parts of nature . Shintoism is a religion that focuses on nature .
 In 1868, the Japanese government established an official religion called State Shinto . Shinto was established in 1868 .
 State Shinto stressed patriotism and the worship of the emperor as a divine being . The emperor was the subject of state Shinto and was a national hero .
 The government abolished State Shinto after World War II, and the emperor declared he was not divine . The emperor declared himself not divine after the war .
 Today, fewer than 3 percent of Japanese practice strict traditional Shinto . Fewer than 3 per cent of Japanese people practice strict Shinto.

 Two Pacific Ocean currents -- the Kuroshio and the Oyashio -- influence Japan’s climate . Two Pacific ocean currents influence Japan's climate .
 The warm, dark blue Kuroshio flows northward along the south coast and along the east coast as far north as Tokyo . The warm and dark blue waters flow northward .
 Oyashio flows southward along the east coasts of Hokkaido and northern Honshu, cooling these areas of Japan . The cold Oyasho flows southwards along the eastern coasts of these areas, cooling them .
 In winter, monsoons from the northwest bring cold air to northern Japan . The cold air is brought in by monsoon monsoon from northwest .
 Heavy snows deposit heavy snows on the country’s northwest coast . These winds gather moisture as they cross the Sea of Japan, which collects moisture .
 During the summer, monsoons blow from the southeast, carrying warm, moist air from the Pacific Ocean . Monsoon rains blow from southeast, bringing warm air from Pacific Ocean in the summer .
 Summer monsoons cause hot, humid weather in the central and southern parts of Japan . Summer monsoon rains are expected to hit Japan in the summer .
 All areas of the country—except eastern Hokkaido, receive at least 40 inches of rain yearly . All areas, except eastern Hokhaido, are at least covered in at least 50 inches of rainfall .
 Japan has two major rainy seasons: from mid-June to early July and in September and October . Japan's rainy season lasts from mid to early to mid-September .

 The size of Japan’s economy ranks second only to that of the U.S. in terms of its gross domestic product . Japan's economy is the second largest in the world, after the United States .
 The GDP is the total value of all goods and services produced within a country yearly . GDP is a total of GDP produced annually in a country . GDP represents the total amount of goods produced annually .
 Japan is one of the world’s leading countries in the value of its exports and imports . The country is also a major source of food and medicine exports .
 On average, Japanese families enjoy one of the highest income levels in the world . Their assets and savings are among the world's largest .
 The country has few natural resources, so it must buy such necessities as aluminum, coal, lead, and petroleum . It must also buy aluminum, . coal, and lead, as well as aluminum .
 To pay for those imports, the government has adopted a strategy of exporting manufactured goods of high value . The government wants to pay for the imports of those goods .
 Japan’s manufactured products range from tiny computer components to giant oceangoing ships . Japan's manufactured products include computer components and oceanglass ships .
 The most important manufactured products are cars and trucks, electronic products, and communications and data processing equipment .
 Other products include cement, ceramics, clothing, fabricated metal products, food products, and food products .
 Japan's manufacturing sector plays a major role in the Japanese economy . The manufacturing sector is a major part of Japan's economy .
 Manufacturing industries have consistently employed more than 20 percent of the Japanese labor force . Manufacturing industries generated approximately 25 percent of Japan’s gross domestic product .
 An especially important part of Japan’s manufacturing sector is known as the /arge-firm sector . The /arge firm sector is a key part of the economy .
 NEC Corporation, Nissan Motor Company, Sony Corporation, Toshiba Corporation, and Toyota Motor Corporation . It includes such well-known companies as NEC, Nissan and Sony .
 Most of the large manufacturing firms assemble parts and components into a finished product such as a car, computer, or television set . Most of these companies assemble components into finished products .
 Large firms sell the product at a significantly higher price than the cost of the components . The large firms then sell it at a much higher price .
 Another part of the manufacturing sector consists of tens of thousands of small factories . The manufacturing sector is based in small factories in China .
 Most of these companies make the parts or components that large firms assemble into finished products . Most of the companies make or assemble the parts of finished products that they make .
 A core group of Japanese managers and skilled workers in the large-firm sector have secure jobs, earn high wages, and enjoy generous benefits . Core group of managers in large firms enjoy secure jobs and high wages .
 Some workers in the large-firm sector and many in the small factories have less job security, lower wages, and fewer benefits . But some workers in large firms and small factories are less secure and have fewer job security .

 Construction sector consists of several giant national firms, hundreds of medium-sized regional firms, and thousands of small local firms . The construction sector is one of the largest in the world .
 The industry grew dramatically after World War II, when construction firms were needed to rebuild Japan's ruined cities and demolished factories . The construction industry grew significantly after the war, when rebuilding Japan's devastated cities .

 Japan has a wide variety of minerals, but supplies of most are too small to satisfy the nation’s needs . Supplies of most of the minerals are small enough to satisfy Japan's needs .
 The chief mining products are coal, copper, lead, limestone, manganese, silver, tin, and zinc . Coal, copper and lead are the chief products of mining .
 Throughout much of Japan's history, agriculture was the mainstay of the Japanese economy . Agriculture has been a major factor in Japan's economy for decades .
 As late as 1950, the agricultural sector employed 45 percent of the labor force . The agricultural sector was at the peak of its peak in 1950s .
 As Japan's industries grew, the economic importance of agriculture declined . Agriculture declined as Japan's industry grew, but agriculture has declined .
 Because Japan is mountainous, only about 15 percent of the land can be cultivated .
 To make their farmland as productive, Japanese farmers use irrigation, improved seed varieties, fertilizers, and modern machinery .
 Farmers grow some crops on terraced fields on level strips of land cut out of hillsides . Some farmers grow crops on levels of land on the hilltops .
 Japan’s farmers are able to produce almost all the eggs, potatoes, rice, and fresh vegetables eaten in Japan . Almost all of the eggs and potatoes are produced in Japan by farmers .
 They produce 50 to 80 percent of dairy products, fruit, and meat . They also produce up to 80 per cent of dairy, fruit and meat products .
 Japan raises only a tiny share of animal feed, beans, and wheat that Japan needs . However, they raise only a small share of the animal feed and beans needed for Japan's needs .
 The nation must import agricultural products that its farmers cannot supply . The nation needs to import the agricultural products it cannot supply. The nation's farmers must supply.
 For decades, government policies have kept crop prices high, especially for rice . Rice prices have been high for decades, especially in rice .
 Japan's policies help ensure that Japan has an adequate supply of food, and protect rural communities from the sudden loss of income . Rural communities are also protected from sudden losses of income, experts say .
 Most Japanese consumers want to reduce government subsidies so that food becomes less expensive . But most want the government to reduce the government subsidies to reduce food prices . The government is expected to reduce subsidies to less expensive food .
 Other nations want Japan to stop protecting its agricultural sector, so that foreigners can sell rice and other farm products to the Japanese . Japan wants foreigners to sell rice, other products to sell to its citizens . Japan has been criticized for protecting agricultural exports .
 Japanese fishing crews catch large amounts of bonito, carp, eel, mackerel, pollock, sardines, trout, and tuna . Fishing crews catch fish in Japan .
 Other products of Japan's fishing industry include crabs and other shellfish and squid .
 Workers also harvest oysters and edible seaweed from "farms" in coastal waters . Oysters and seaweed are also harvested from coastal waters in Australia .

 Service industries generate over 60 percent of Japan’s GDP and employ more than 60 percent the labor force . Taken altogether, service industries generate more than 80 percent of the country's labor force.
 Japan’s leading service industries include finance, insurance, real estate, and real estate . The country's leading services industries include community, social, and personal services; finance, . real estate and wholesale and retail trade .
 Other service industries that contribute to Japan’s economy include government, transportation and communication . Government and transportation industries contribute to the economy .
 Many of the workers in the service industries are highly educated and well-paid . Many of these workers are well-educated and well paid .
 They include bankers, financial analysts, civil servants, engineers, teachers, accountants, doctors, and lawyers . They hold such positions as bankers, analysts, teachers and accountants .
 Salarymen enjoy good job security until they retire in their late 50's or early 60's . Salarymen receive generous incomes and benefits, according to experts .
 A number of other workers in the service industries earn lower salaries and have fewer benefits and little job security . However, a number of service workers in that industry earn less salaries .
 Such shops sell food, clothing, household necessities, and a variety of other goods . Shops sell food and clothing .

 Japan ranks among the world’s leading consumers of electric power . Nevertheless, Japan is one of the most populous countries in the world .

 In many ways, the driving force of Japan’s economy is international trade . International trade is the key to Japan's success in the country's economy .
 By trading with other nations, Japan obtains raw materials it does not have and finds buyers for the expensive, highquality manufactured goods its workers produce . Japan's workers produce high quality, high-quality products .
 Other major imports include chemicals, fish and shellfish, and metal ores . The U.S. imports include fish, chemicals, shellfish and metals .
 Japan buys many of its imports from Asian nations with small populations and few consumers . Japan buys imports from countries with few consumers, such as Japan .
 Japan is seldom able to sell to its trade partners enough manufactured goods to maintain an equal balance of imports and exports . As a consequence, Japan's trade partners are unable to sell enough to maintain equal trade and import balance .

 In the 1950's, the United States purchased inexpensive Japanese textile products . The U.S. purchased inexpensive textile products from Japan .
 Later, it began to buy more costly goods, such as automobiles and communications and computer equipment . Later, the government began to purchase more costly items such as cars and communications .
 The United States sells Japan many American goods in return, including expensive items, such as computers and medicines . The U.S. sells the goods to Japan in return for more than $1 billion .
 By the 1980's, the U.S. was buying far more from Japan than it was selling to it . The United States was buying more than its selling to Japan .

 Japan’s trade surpluses enabled it to accumulate huge reserves of foreign currency, in an amount that was second only to the foreign reserves of the United States .

 They also learned how to make tools and weapons out of bronze and iron . The team also learned to make weapons and weapons from bronze .
 By the end of the Yayoi era, different groups of extended families began to struggle for power in the Yamato Plain .
 When the leaders of these groups died, their relatives buried them in large tombs called ko/fun that were often shaped like keyholes . The leaders were buried in tombs shaped like keysholes .
 Many haniwa are figurines of warriors or sculptures of bows and arrows . Haniwa is a sign that warfare had become an important part of Japanese society .
 One of the extended family groups began to dominate the others, and it declared itself Japan's imperial household . In the 600's and 700’s, one of the . extended family . groups began . dominating the others .
 The head of the imperial house, whose given name was Kotoku, became emperor in 645 . His given name is Kotoku .
 The next year, the imperial family began a program called the Taika Reform . The program was the first of its kind .
 The program involved constructing capital cities and organizing Japanese society following the example of China . Japan's capital cities were built following China's example .
 The imperial family created a central government and official bureaus and adopted a system of land management similar to China’s . Imperial family also created a system similar to that of China .
 Under this system, most people worked as farmers on land owned by the government . The government owned most of the land .
 Farmers paid taxes to the government and provided labor, including service in the government's small armies . In return, farmers paid taxes, provided labor to government in return for their services .
 To justify its claim to authority, the imperial family relied not on China but on ancient Japanese beliefs . The imperial family used ancient beliefs to justify its authority .
 Japanese histories maintain that the family had descended from the gods who created the Japanese islands in mythology .
 The family’s presumed descent was through Amaterasu, the Japanese sun goddess, Amaterasu .
 In 794, the imperial household moved to a new capital city called Heian-kyo, located at the site of today’s Kyoto . The imperial family moved to the new capital, located in the city of today's Kyoto .

 Japan 53 During the Heian era, a male in the imperial household ruled as emperor . During this era, the emperor ruled as an emperor . Japan is now Japan's most populous country .
 The male heads of noble families assisted the emperor by administering the government, collecting tax revenues, maintaining small armies, and judging legal disputes . The head of a noble family was the head of the emperor .
 These officials earned generous incomes and lived in large mansions in the capital city . They lived in mansions .

 Private estates were plots of land whose owners were free from government interference and taxation . Private estates are plots of plots of free land that owners own free of government interference or taxation .
 The government began to establish these estates in the 700’s to provide Buddhist temples and Shinto shrines with income to fund their religious activities .
 During the 700’s, the government also began to allow tax exemptions to those who developed new lands for growing rice .
 The aristocratic families and religious institutions that had enough wealth to develop new lands acquired large holdings . The aristocrats had large holdings of land .

 About half of the rice-growing land in Japan had been converted into private estates . By the 1200's, about half of Japan's rice growing land had been turned into estates .
 As the influence of the private estate owners increased, the power of the central government declined . Private estate owners became more influential to the government in the 1930s .
 With less public land, the government had less tax revenue to support its activities . The government had to rely heavily on public land in order to keep afloat .

 In the late 1100's, the Taira and Minamoto clashed in a series of battles for power .

 The Tokugawa shogun presided over a delicately balanced system of authority . He ruled over a delicate balance of authority in Japan .
 The shogun directly controlled about 25 percent of the farmland in the country . He was directly involved in the development of the country's farmland .
 He also licensed foreign trade, operated gold mines, and ruled the major cities, including Kyoto, Osaka, and the shogun’s capital—Edo, which is now Tokyo .
 The Tokugawa shogun had to share authority with the daimyo, who controlled 75 percent of Japan’s farmland . The daimy controlled most of Japan's farmland .
 In each han, the daimyo, not the shogun, issued laws and collected taxes . The shogun issued laws, collected taxes and issued laws in each of the han han .
 During the Tokugawa era, Japan had only a partially centralized government . Japan thus had a partially central government .
 The Tokugawa did not support Christianity, the religion of most of the outsiders . Their presence disturbed the shogun, in part because of the lack of support for Christianity . The shogun did not want the outsiders to live in Japan .
 The shogun wanted to control Japan's international trade to prevent any daimyo from gaining too much wealth and power through trade with the outsiders .

 The fleet's commander, Matthew C Perry, has asked Japan to open its ports to international trade .

 In 1858, Harris succeeded in his negotiations on behalf of the United States, and Japan signed a treaty of commerce . The treaty was signed by the U.S. and Japan .
 The treaty permitted trade between the two countries, called for opening five Japanese ports to international commerce . It also gave the U.S. the right to extraterritoriality .
 This right enabled American citizens to be governed only by U.S. laws while they were on Japanese soil . This right was granted to American citizens in Japan .
 Many Japanese disapproved of the treaty and similar agreements signed later . The treaty was signed in 1903 .
 To them, the treaties were unequal, because Japan had granted extraterritoriality and other privileges that were not given to the Japanese in turn . To them they said, "to them, it was unequal" to them .
 The treaties enraged many samurai, who attacked some foreign officials . Many samurai attacked some officials, killing them .

 Japanese print is a type of Japanese illustration printed on paper from carved blocks of wood . It is printed on a piece of wood carved from carved wood .
 The most famous Japanese prints were produced from the 1600's to the late 1800's . They were created from the 16th century to 18th century .
 They are noted for their brilliant designs, bold colors, and technical quality . They are also noted for the brilliant designs and bold colors .
 Most Japanese prints portray scenes from everyday life or from the theater and other popular forms of entertainment .
 They called the prints ukivo-e, which means pictures of the floating world . The prints were printed in Japan in the 1930s .
 Japanese prints were designed by highly trained artists and produced by skilled artisans . Prints are designed by skilled artists and are made of Japanese materials .
 The early prints were made in black and white, though the artists sometimes added other colors by hand . The prints were often made by hand, with the artists adding other colors .
 A carver cut away portions of the wood between the lines of the drawing, which left the design itself raised . The design itself was raised by a carver .
 A printer then applied a water-based ink to the raised surfaces of the wood block . The printer then used the ink to apply to the surface of the block .
 The printer rubbed the back of the paper with a smooth-surfaced pad, and the ink soaked into the paper . The printer rubs a smooth surface on the back with the ink, and it soaked in the ink .
 The printer then pulled the paper from the block, and the design appeared in print . The printer pulled the design from a block and it was printed in print.
 The production of color prints required additional blocks of wood, one for each color used . The color prints were printed with wood blocks, with each color being made .
 The carver cut each block so that the only areas left raised were those to be used for a certain color . The only areas raised were the ones used for the color used for certain colors .
 The printer applied various colored pastes to the blocks and placed the paper on each block in succession . The printer then applied various colors to each block .
 Japanese prints originated in the early 1600s as illustrations in popular books . Prints originated in Japan as illustrations for popular books in the 1600s .
 Many people became interested in the pictures themselves, so publishers began producing illustrations separately from books . Publishers began to produce illustrations separately, and so publishers produced them separately .

 He held that philosophy is not a set of doctrines, but an activity through which individuals can become aware of the nature of their own existence . He said philosophy was not about doctrines but about how individuals become aware .
 He held that in philosophy all content and all conclusions are unimportant . However, he was not primarily interested in the philosophers’ conclusions .

 Ivan Soll Jaundice, /AWN dihs, is a yellowish discoloration of the skin, the tissues, and whites of the eyes .
 It results from an increased amount of bi//irubin, a reddish-yellow pigment, in the blood . It is an increase in the red color in the human blood . The pigment is a red-red pigment .
 Bilirubin is formed by the breakdown of hemoglobin, a pigment in red blood cells . It is formed from the breakdowns of the red blood cell's hemoglobin .
 The liver removes bilirubin from the blood stream and discharges it in the bile . The liver then removes the   from the  blood stream, discharges  in bile.
 Jasper National Park, in western Alberta, includes many scenic peaks, including Mount Edith Cavell, above . Jaundice results from either excessive production of bilirubin or reduced discharge .
 Jaundice in dogs, sheep, and other animals is sometimes called yellows . It is also sometimes called jaundice .
 Hemolytic jaundice results from an increased breakdown of red blood cells, which causes a greater concentration of bilirubin in the blood . Hemolyt jaundic jaundices are often caused by increased red blood cell breakdown .
 Hepatocellular jaundice occurs when the liver is damaged so that it cannot secrete enough bile bile . It is caused by damage to the liver so it can no longer secrete bile.
 Many babies are born with physiologic jaundice, which occurs if the body cannot process all the bilirubin it produces . The jaundic baby is often born with jaundiced skin .

 Jazz Jazz is a kind of music that has often been called the only art form to originate in the United States . Jazz Jazz has been described as the only form of jazz music that originated in the US .
 The music grew fram a combination of influences, including black American music, African rhythms, American band traditions and instruments, and European harmonies and forms .
 Much of the best jazz is still written and performed in the United States . Much of it is still played in the jazz world .
 Musicians from many other countries are making major contributions to jazz . But musicians from other countries also contribute to jazz.
 Jazz was widely appreciated as an important art form in Europe before it gained such recognition in the U.S. Jazz was actually widely appreciated by Europeans before it became more popular in the United States .
 One of the key elements of jazz is improvisation, the ability to create new music spontaneously . Jazz improvisation is an essential part of jazz .
 This skill is the distinguishing characteristic of a genuine jazz musician . Jazz is not just jazz, but jazz is jazz .
 Improvisation raises the role of the soloist from just a performer and reproducer of others’ ideas to a composer as well . The soloist is now a composer and soloist .
 To syncopate their music, jazz musicians take patterns that are even and regular and break them up, make them uneven, and put accents in unexpected places . Jazz musicians break patterns into patterns and make accents uneven and accentuate them .
 The earliest jazz was performed by black Americans who had little or no training in Western music . It was performed in black Americans with little or little Western training .

 The development of instruments with new and different characteristics has also influenced the sound of jazz . Jazz has also been influenced by instruments with different characteristics, such as new instruments .
 Jazz may be performed by a single musician, by a small group of musicians called a combo, or by a big band of 10 or more pieces . The sound of jazz Jazz is similar to the sound of a jazz ensemble .
 The typical front line consists of one to five brass and reed instruments . Front line is made up of one-to-five brass instruments .
 The rhythm section usually consists of piano, bass, drums, and sometimes acoustic or electric guitar . It is usually accompanied by a rhythm rhythm section .
 The rhythm section in a combo or big band maintains the steady beat and decorates the rhythm with syncopated patterns . Rhythm sections in a big band maintain the rhythmic beat .
 The drums keep the beat steady and add interesting rhythm patterns and syncopations .
 The piano plays the chords or harmonies of a composition in a rhythmic manner . The piano, or sometimes a guitar, plays the harmonies in rhythmic ways .
 The bass outlines the harmonies by sounding the roots, or bottom pitches, of the chords, on the strong beats of each measure . The bottom pitches are the roots of each chord and the top pitches of each beat .
 Any of the rhythm instruments, especially the piano, may also solo during a performance .
 The principal brass instruments of jazz are the trumpet, the cornet, and the slide trombone . The trumpet is the most powerful instrument in jazz . The cornet is the saxophone, the sax saxophonist is the trumpeter .
 French horn, valve trombone, baritone horn, fliigelhorn, and even electronic trumpets used in jazz performances .

 The typical brass section of a big band consists of four or five trumpets and three trombones . Typical brass section is four trumpets, five trombone and three trumpets . A typical big band's brass section consists of six trumpets per piece .
 Jazz trumpeters and trombonists frequently use objects called mutes to alter or vary the sound of their instrument . Mutes are mutes used to alter the sounds of their instruments .
 The player plugs the mute into the be// (flared end) of the instrument or holds it close to the opening of the bell . The mute is placed in the player's ear or the player holds it to the be // .

 Only extremely skilled musicians were able to play bebop well, and only sophisticated listeners at first appreciated it . Bebop was a form of jazz that first appeared in the jazz world .
 In bebop performances, musicians usually played an intricate melody, followed with long periods of solo improvisation, and restated the theme at the end of the piece .
 The bassist presented the basic beat for the group by plucking a steady, moving bass line . The group's bassist played a steady bass line during the performance .
 The drummer elaborated the beat with sticks or brushes on cymbals, snare drum, and tom-tom . The drummer elaborates the beat using sticks, brushes or brushes .
 The pianist inserted complex chords at irregular intervals to suggest, rather than state, the complete harmonies of the piece .
 This form emphasized some of the traditional values of jazz derived from gospel and blues music, including rhythmic drive, uninhibited tone and volume, and freedom from restricting arrangements .

 The memorial is a white marble building on the south side of the Tidal Basin near the Potomac River . It is located in the area known as the National Mall .

 A neighborhood known as Mea Shearim, north of downtown, is the home of many Orthodox Jews . The neighborhood is known for its Orthodox Jewish traditions .
 The huge Hadassah Medical Center stands nearby, with its famous stained glass windows designed by Marc Chagall . The Russian-born artist designed the windows .
 Also in the area is Yad Vashem, a memorial museum dedicated to the victims of the Holocaust, the Nazi campaign to exterminate the Jews . Also in Israel, the Holocaust museum is dedicated to victims .
 East Jerusalem, north of the Old City, is where most of Jerusalem's Arabs live . East Jerusalem is home to most of the city's Arab population .
 Some neighborhoods in East Jerusalem are run-down, with old, neglected housing . East Jerusalem is one of the poorest parts of the city .
 Israel built several modern Jewish neighborhoods, including Ramat Eshkol and Gilo, after taking control of East Jerusalem in 1967 . Israel took control of the city in 1967 and built several new Jewish neighborhoods .
 Jerusalem has a central place in the worship, doctrine, and daily practice of Judaism, Christianity, and islam . Holy places Jerusalem is central to the worship and doctrine of all three major religions .
 The city’s large number of synagogues, churches, mosques, and other religious institutions reflects the significance of the city for all three faiths . The city has more than 1,000 synogues .
 According to tradition, Jerusalem is where God ordered the patriarch Abraham to sacrifice his son, Isaac, to Him . The city is where Abraham's son Isaac was sacrificed to God .
 The Jews built their Temple, the center of Jewish worship in ancient times, at the site of Abraham's sacrifice on the Temple Mount in the Old City . The Temple Mount is the site where Abraham's sacrificed to the Jews .
 Two successive buildings, the First Temple and the Second Temple, stood at the site . The First and Second Temple were built at the same time .
 The First Temple housed the Ark of the Covenant, a sacred chest holding the tablets inscribed with the Ten Commandments . The Ark was housed in the First Temple, the sacred chest containing the tablets . It was the first temple to be built in the city's First Temple .
 The Western Wall is the only surviving part of the Second Temple and Judaism’s most sacred shrine . It is considered the most sacred and most sacred of all holy places in Judaism .
 It is a stone retaining wall that reinforced the western side of the Temple Mount in ancient times . The wall was built on the west side of Temple Mount . It is one of the largest retaining walls in the world .
 The wall is sometimes called the Wailing Wall because of the sorrowful prayers said there to mourn the destroyed Temple . It is sometimes known as the Wail Wall .
 Other sites in the city sacred to the Jews include King David's tomb on Mount Zion in West Jerusalem and the Jewish Cemetery and the Tombs of the Prophets on the Mount of Olives .
 Many sites associated with Biblical figures are sacred to Christians, too . They include those associated with biblical figures such as Jesus Christ .
 Many monasteries, convents, shrines and religious seminaries in Jerusalem mark events in the life of Jesus Christ and in the formation of the Christian Church .

 The prophet redirected his followers to face Mecca instead of Jerusalem when praying, to symbolize the independence of Islam . However, the prophet changed his followers' view of Mecca .

 Jerusalem's Jewish citizens also differ in the extent of which they follow the laws and practices of Judaism . Jerusalem's Jews differ in how they follow Jewish law and practices .
 Some people, called secular Jews, have a strong sense of Jewish identity but observe few religious traditions . Some secular Jews observe few Jewish traditions, such as a Jewish identity .
 A group of extremely traditional Orthodox Jews called haredim make up about a third of Jerusalem’s Jews . They are the fastest-growing group in the city and are the most traditional Jews .
 Many haredim follow ways of life that developed among Jewish communities in Eastern Europe, Spain, and North Africa hundreds of years ago .
 Many haredim speak a Germanic language called Yiddish along with Hebrew . They dress in traditional styles of the 1800's .
 Many of the men wear long black coats, black or fur-trimmed hats, and beards or dangling side curls . The men wear beards, beards and dangling side hair .
 The women typically wear long coats and dresses, black stockings, and headscarves or wigs to follow religious laws that call for modesty .
 Confrontations have occasionally developed between Jews of different religious convictions over observances of Jewish law . Jews of differing religious convictions sometimes confront each other over observance of law .
 Many extremely religious Jews believe that only a life of prayer and religious study is proper for the holy city .
 They also have demanded that their neighborhood streets be closed to traffic during the Jewish Sabbath, from sundown Friday to sundown Saturday .
 They believe only the Messiah, whom God will send, can establish the Jewish state . They believe that only God will establish the state .

 Jesuits, /EHZH u ihts or JEHZ uh wihts, are members of a Roman Catholic religious order of men . Don B Wilmeth Jesuits are the Jesuits of the Netherlands .
 Order operates more than 4,000 schools, colleges, and universities throughout the world . The order operates 4,500 schools and colleges around the globe .
 Jesuits direct about 45 high schools and 28 colleges and universities in the United States . In the U.S. Jesuits have directed about 45 schools, 28 universities . Jesuits also direct schools in Europe, Africa and Africa .
 The Order has produced many important explorers, missionaries, scientists, theologians, and writers . The order has produced important explorers and missionaries .
 St. Francis Xavier converted thousands of people in the Far East during the 1500s . Saint Francis Xavier, a Spanish Jesuit, converted thousands .
 Jacques Marquette, a French Jesuit, helped explore the Mississippi River in the late 1600's . Marquette explored the river in the 16th century . He was the first Jesuit to explore the river on the Mississippi .
 Gerard Manley Hopkins, an English Jesuit, was one of the leading poets of the 1800's . Hopkins was a Jesuit and Jesuit . Hopkins is one of England's most famous poets .
 Pierre Teilhard de Chardin, a French Jesuit, became a leading pa/eonto/ogist (expert on prehistoric life) and theologian in the 1900s . He was a leading expert in prehistoric life .
 The best-known Jesuit saints include Robert Bellarmine, Peter Canisius, and Isaac Jogues . The Jesuit saints are known for their work in Spain .
 Jesuit begins two years of spiritual training after entering the order . Membership and training is required for the order's members .
 After training, he takes vows of poverty and obedience to his superiors . After training he vows to be poor and obey orders of obedience .
 The brothers are full members of the order but not ordained to the priesthood . They are not ordained as priests . The brothers have been married for more than 20 years .
 The professed take a vow of special obedience to the pope in addition to taking vows of celibacy, obedience, and poverty .
 Jesuits must study for many years before becoming spiritual coadjutors or professors . Jesuits have to study for years before they become professors or spiritual leaders . Jesuit must study in order to become a professor or spiritual leader .
 This period of study, which usually lasts about 15 years for a high school graduate, provides both spiritual and academic training . This period, which lasts 15 years, is usually 15 years .
 Jesuits superiors determine if he is qualified for the rank of professed . A Jesuits superior decides whether he is a professed member .
 They base their decision on the individual's record in his studies and on his qualities of spiritual leadership, they say . The decision was made on the basis of their decision .
 For administrative purposes, the order is divided into regions called provinces, viceprovinces, and mission territories . The provinces are called provinces and viceprovvinces .
 An official called a provincial supervises each province and vice-province . The official supervises the provinces and vice provinces .
 Provinces that share a common Janguage or cultural background are grouped together into ass/stancies . Provincing provinces that share common language or cultural backgrounds are grouped into ass-stancies.
 An assistant serves as an adviser to the superior general on matters involving each assistancy . An assistant is a member of the supervisory council .
 The superior general is elected for life by a congregation made up of assistants, provincials, and delegates from the order . A congregation of delegates is also elected delegates from order .
 The congregation elects several principal assistants to the superior general . The congregation also elects a principal assistant .
 In 1544, the pope authorized the order to increase its membership without limit . The pope also authorized the pope to increase the membership of the order .
 Ignatius wrote the order's constitutions, which have become models for hundreds of other Roman Catholic religious communities . The order was founded in 1881 and is now based in New York City .
 Under Ignatius, the Jesuits grew to almost 1,000 members . The Jesuits were founded in 17th century . Ignatsius was the first Jesuit to become a leader .

 The principle of jet propulsion can be demonstrated with a garden hose connected to a water supply . A garden hose can be used to demonstrate the principle .
 When the nozzle at the end of the hose is closed, the water pushes in all directions against the inside of the nozzle . The water pushes against the outside of the closed nozzle in a bid to push the water inside .
 It also pushes back against the water in the hose that is trying to squeeze into the nozzle . The nozzle is also pushing back against water that's trying to get into the hose .
 When the nozzle is open, some of the water squirts out through the opening of the opening . The nozzle is used to spray water out of the nozzle when it is open .
 The nozzle releases the pressure pushing forward just inside the nozzle opening . The nozzle is then released to release the pressure inside .
 Water that is still in the nozzle continues pressing backward and to the sides of the nozzle . The nozzle is still pressing forward and back, but the water continues to press forward and to sides .
 If you let go of the nozzle, the unbalanced, backward-pushing pressure will propel it backward . The nozzle will move backwards if it is not balanced and unbalanced .
 The nozzle will move in the direction opposite that of the jet of water escaping from the nozzle . The nozzle of water will move opposite the direction of the nozzle of a nozzle .
 The principle of jet propulsion was first described in 1687 by Sir Isaac Newton in his third law of motion .
 This law states that for every action, there is an equal and opposite reaction . This law says for every reaction, there should be an equal or opposite reaction to every action .
 The equal and opposite reaction is the backward movement of the nozzle . The equal reaction is to the movement of a nozzle .
 The pressure pushing in one direction is released in a powerful stream of jet exhaust . Jet exhaust is released by a powerful jet stream that pushes in one way .
 The action of this exhaust escaping from the rear of the engine causes an equal and opposite reaction that pushes the engine forward . The action is similar to the action of the opposite reaction pushing the car forward .

 The job of the inlet duct becomes more complicated in jet fighters and other aircraft that fly faster than the speed of sound .
 Supersonic flight causes shock waves to develop in the air as it rushes through the inlet duct . The shock waves are caused by shock waves from the air rushing through the air .
 Shock waves remove energy from the air, which can reduce the engine's thrust . These shock waves can also reduce the thrust of the engine .
 A turbojet can reduce the loss of energy caused by shock waves by adjusting the shape of the inside of the inlet duct . The shape of a turbojet duct can also be adjusted to reduce energy loss caused by such shock waves .
 Turbojets are equipped with either an axia/flow compressor or a centrifugal-flow compressor . Turbojet is equipped with two-compound compressors: axia-flow and centrifugal flow compressors .
 An axial-flow compressor consists of several wheels with many small, winglike blades attached, as in an electric fan . The compressor is a compressor with several wheels attached to it . The blades are attached to the wheels of the compressors .
 These wheels are arranged one behind another along a shaft that runs through their centers and turns them at high speeds . The shaft is used to turn the wheels along a path that turns them around .
 Some axialflow compressors raise the air pressure to a level about 40 times that of the air entering the inlet duct . Some compressors can also raise the pressure to 40 times the level of air coming into the ducts .
 A centrifugal-flow compressor squeezes the air by taking it in near the center of a rapidly spinning wheel and throwing it out toward the rim . The air is squeezed by the air in a centrifugal flow of air .
 They are used less frequently in turbojet engines than axial-flow compressors are . As a result, they are less frequently used as compressors in turbo engines .

 Jet stream is a band of fast-moving air currents that occur at high altitudes . Jet stream occurs at a high altitude .
 Jet streams flow in wavelike fashion around the Northern and Southern hemispheres . Jet streams travel in a similar way around the world .
 They change position constantly and move both vertically and horizontally . They are constantly changing their positions constantly .
 A jet stream’''s core of strongest winds is about 60 miles wide and about 1 mile (1. kilometers) thick . The core of the strongest winds in a jet stream is about 1.5 miles thick .
 There are three main jet streams in the upper troposphere, the layer of the atmosphere nearest the earth .
 They occur at altitudes of 6 to 9 miles (10 to 15 kilometers) above the ground . They can be seen in the U.S. National Park .
 These three jet streams are the polar jet, subtropical jet, and equatorial jet . The polar jet stream is the one of the three main jet streams in the world . These three streams are known as the equatorial jets .
 The polar jet and subtropical jet both weaken during the summer and move farther north . The sub-tropical jet and polar jet weaken in the summer, moving further north .
 Other jet streams occur at higher altitudes than those found in the troposphere . Jet streams are found at higher altitude than the tropospheric jet streams .
 For example, the po/ar night jetis is in the stratosphere, the atmospheric layer above the troposphere . For instance, it's in the atmosphere of the Earth .
 Jet streams were not widely known until World War II . American and German pilots encountered them at high altitudes . Jet streams are not known until WWII .
 The jet streams shown on these maps occur in the troposphere, the layer of the atmosphere closest to the earth . These maps are based on data from the International Meteorological Organisation .
 These air currents flow from west to east, except the one nearest the equator . These currents flow to the north and south of the world's poles .
 The force of the winds in and near jet streams may cause aircraft in their vicinity to experience turbulence .
 Air currents are often associated with storms and even tornadoes . These air currents often accompany storms and are associated with tornadoes.
 Wayne M Wendland Jetty is a pier or wal] built out from the shore of a river, lake, or ocean to control the flow of water . It is built out of the shore from a river or lake to control water flow .
 A jetty at a river mouth or harbor entrance may deepen a channel leading into the river or harbor so that ships will not run aground . It may be used to keep ships from running aground at the mouth of a river .
 A jetty also may extend a channel in order to prevent sand from blocking the channel's mouth . The channel may also be extended to avoid sand blocking the mouth .
 A type of jetty called a groin protects shores from erosion by trapping sand and silt . A groin is a type of jetties that trap sand, silt and sand from shorelines .
 Jetties may be made of timber, stone, concrete, or steel, sometimes in combination with sand . They are made of concrete, timber, concrete or steel .
 A jetty deepens a channel by narrowing it, causing the water flowing out of the channel to move faster . The water flowing from the jetty can be seen flowing faster in the channel .
 The faster-moving water picks up more particles of sand or mud from the bottom of the channel, thus deepening it . It picks up particles from bottom of channel, so deepening it, so deeper it can be deeper .
 U.S. Army Corps of Engineers, Portland District make the current carry sand away from the mouth of a channel . In areas where currents deposit sand around a channel's mouth, a jetty can extend the length of the channel .
 The Columbia River, which empties into the Pacific Ocean, has one of the world’s longest jetties . Columbia River is the longest in the world .
 The harbor has a mechanically dredged channel 55 to 60 feet (17 to 18 meters) deep . The harbor is 55-60 feet deep and has a mechanical dredging channel .

 Job Corps is a U.S. government program that provides job training, education, and other services for disadvantaged young men and women . Job Corps was created by the United States Department of Justice in 1964 . The Job Corps program is a federal government program .
 The basic goal of the program is to teach job skills to people who range in age from 16 to 22 years old . The program is aimed at teaching people job skills in the workplace .
 Job Corps also offers counseling, health care, job placement, and classroom instruction to finish high school . The Job Corps is also offering counseling and health care .
 More than 75 percent of the people who complete the program find a job, return to school, or join the armed forces .
 Job Corps provides its services in residential centers in the United States and Puerto Rico . The Job Corps is based in Puerto Rico and the U.S.
 Most of the young men and women stay at a center for six months of training, but some remain as long as two years . Most of them stay at the centers for about six months . Some of the training centers are located in the United States .
 Most of the centers serve people from a particular state or region and design their programs to meet job needs in that locality . The centers are designed to meet the job needs of people in that area .
 At many centers, labor unions offer special apprenticeship programs in such construction trades as bricklaying, carpentry, and the operation of heavy equipment . At some centers, for example, labor union offers special apprenticeships programs .
 The corps was administered by the Office of Economic Opportunity until 1969 . It was transferred to the Department of Labor in 1969 .

 Peter Sullivan Johanson, Donald Carl, is an American anthropologist . Donald Carl is an authority on human origins . He is an anthropologist who has published numerous books .
 A 1974 expedition led by Johanson at Hadar, Ethiopia, discovered the fossilized remains of what is now commonly regarded as one of the earliest types of humanlike creatures that walked upright .
 The fossils, from a creature nicknamed “Lucy, are between 3 million and 3,600,000 years old . The fossils are from an ancient creature nicknamed Lucy . They are thought to be between 3,000,000 and 3 million years old, dating back to 3,

 Secret Service agent guarding Johnson shoved him to the floor of the car and lay over him . After the assassin fired his first shot, the Secret Service officer lay over Johnson . Johnson was shot in the head by the assassin .
 An hour and 39 minutes after Kennedy died, Johnson was sworn in as the 36th President of the United States .
 The ceremony took place at 2:39m. aboard the presidential Air Force jet at Love Field in Dallas .
 At Johnson‘s request, the oath of office was administered by an old friend, United States District Court Judge Sarah T Hughes .
 The Cold War with the Soviet Union and other Communist countries kept the world in danger of a nuclear war . The world was at risk of nuclear war during the Cold War .
 In Vietnam, Communist rebels fought troops supported by the U.S. in Vietnam . They fought against the government's efforts to defeat the Communist government .
 Racial tension and a high unemployment rate were the main problems that plagued the U.S. The United States was plagued by racial tension and unemployment rates .
 Major parts of the Administration's program were bogged down in Congress . The Administration's plan for the program is still under way in the process .
 Communist agents in Central and South America threatened democratic governments . Communist agents threatened governments in South America . Communists were behind the rise of the Soviet Union .
 As the first days passed, the country felt the impact of a new, but experienced, leader . President Barack Obama took office in December .
 Stock prices went back up when the exchanges opened after the funeral . Stock values had dropped sharply at the news of Kennedy's death .
 The President pushed hard for legislation that had been proposed by President Kennedy . President Kennedy pushed for legislation .
 He urged quick passage of a tax cut and a strong civil rights bill, both Kennedy measures . The president also called for a strong tax cut . Kennedy urged the passage of both measures .
 This was $500 million less than the previous budget, and $2 billion less than most people had expected . The budget was $1.2 billion lower than expected . This is the first time the budget has been reduced to $1 billion .
 This program included creating new jobs and building up areas where the economy had faltered . This program includes creating jobs in areas that had falered .
 Congress also passed a new civil rights law . It cut taxes for both individuals and corporations .
 This law opened to blacks all hotels, motels, restaurants, and other businesses that serve the public . This law was passed by Congress in 1996 .
 The railroad crisis, in April 1964, plunged Johnson into one of the toughest U.S. labor disputes . The rail crisis was the first of its kind in the United States .
 The railroads and the union members who ran the trains had been battling over work rules for almost five years . Railroads and union members had been fighting over the rules for years .
 The companies say outdated rules forced them to hire workers no longer needed . The companies said outdated rules made them hire workers that are not needed .
 Under pressure from Johnson, the two negotiating teams settled the dispute in only 12 days . The dispute was settled in just 12 days after Johnson's intervention .
 Johnson conferred with many of the world leaders who came to Kennedy's funeral . Johnson confer with world leaders .
 Johnson telephoned Panama's president and agreed to discuss outstanding problems . Tensions eased after Johnson agreed to meet with Panama's leader to discuss issues .
 The United States continued its technical and financial assistance to South Vietnam against the Viet Cong . The U.S. continued to assist South Vietnam in the war .
 The Viet Cong were Communist-supported guerrilla forces from North and South Vietnam . Viet Cong was a Communist-backed guerrilla force from the communist-supported South Vietnam.
 On August 4, Johnson announced that the North Vietnamese had again launched an attack in the gulf, this time against the Maddox and another U.S. destroyer, the C Turner Joy .
 Some Americans doubted that the August 4 attack had occurred, and the attack has never been confirmed . The attack was never confirmed .
 Johnson ordered United States planes to bomb North Vietnam's torpedo-boat bases . Nevertheless, Johnson ordered U.S. troops to bomb the bases . Johnson ordered the bombing of the bases in Vietnam .
 On August 7, Congress approved these powers in the Tonkin Gulf Resolution . Congress also approved the resolution on August 7 .
 Johnson used the resolution as a legal basis for increased U.S. involvement in the war . The resolution was used to justify increased US involvement in Afghanistan .
 He showed great energy, often speaking several times a day at widely separated places, then going back to his desk in Washington .
 He entertained many guests there, and usually gave them big, wide-brimmed Texas hats . He entertained them there .

 Johnson tried to keep life normal for her daughters, but this was sometimes impossible . Johnson: "I'm sorry for what happened to me, but I'm not so sure about it"

 She was the first daughter of a President to marry while her father was in office since Eleanor Wilson in 1914 . She was first daughter to marry during her father's presidency since 1914 .
 Johnson entertained graciously, and usually included dancing at White House social functions .

 He stood between his wife, /eff, and Jacqueline Kennedy, the widow of the slain President . He stood next to his wife and the Kennedy widow . He said he stood between the two women .
 The term Great Society caught on, and was used to describe many of the President's domestic programs . The term 'Great Society' caught on .
 These programs included continuing the War on Poverty, improving the educational system, providing for elder citizens, and providing for urban areas .

 Among other things, the law outlawed literacy tests as a voting requirement . The law also outlawed literacy testing as a voter registration requirement .

 A new housing law, also passed in 1968, provided over $5 billion in federal funds to help the needy buy houses and rent apartments . The law was passed by Congress in 1968 .

 A bitter debate developed in the United States over the U.S. role in the war . The United States played a key role in World War II .

 Johnson Space Center is the headquarters for all astronaut projects conducted by the National Aeronautics and Space Administration of the United States . The center is headquarters for NASA's space exploration efforts .
 The space center serves as training headquarters for United States astronauts . It is located in California, California .
 Mission Control Center at the space center controls the flight . Mission Control controls the launch of a space flight from Cape Canaveral, Florida .
 Mission Control monitors the various systems that keep the astronauts alive and the spacecraft functioning . Mission Control is responsible for the mission to the Mars Mars mission .
 Engineers supervise the design, development, and construction of spacecraft . Engineers at the space center supervise space center's spacecraft design .
 The vehicles are built in factories and then checked thoroughly at the space center . They are then sent to the space lab for testing .
 Special chambers reproduce flight vibrations, the vacuum of space, and the great temperature changes in space and on the moon . Special chambers at the space center reproduce flight vibration and the temperature changes of space and moon .
 Construction of the Manned Spacecraft Center began in 1962 . The center became the headquarters of the U.S. astronaut program in 1964 .
 Scientists and engineers at the center directed the first landing of astronauts on the moon in July 1969 . The first landing took place on July 4, 1969 .
 The space center was renamed in February 1973 after the death of former President Lyndon B Johnson . It was renamed after former President Johnson .

 William C Rense Joint is the place at which two or more bones meet in the skeleton of the body . Joint is a place where bones meet at a joint in the body's skeleton . Joint joint is a joint place at the place where two bones meet .
 Fixed joints are seams between bones that lie directly against each other, or are separated only by a thin layer of connective tissue . Fixed joints can be found in the U.S. National Museum of Medicine .
 These joints absorb just enough shock to keep the bones from breaking . In case of a blow or an accident, these joints may absorb enough shock .
 The joints of the cranium (covering the brain) are fixed and protect the brain . The joints of the brain are fixed, protecting the brain from harm .
 Hinge joints are those that permit a forward and backward motion in one plane, like the motion of a door on its hinges . The hinge joints allow a backward and forward motion, like a door hinge .
 Pivot joints give a rotating motion, such as the movement of the head from side to side . The joints are used to move the head of a person from side-to-side .
 These joints are made up of a large round end of a long bone that fits into the hollow of another bone . These joints can be found in the bones of a person with a large bone .
 The arms of the body can move more freely than the legs because of the way that the joints are arranged, and because the shoulder blade is only loosely attached to the chest wall . The arms are more likely to move freely than legs because the way they are arranged .
 A smooth layer of cartilage covers the ends of bones that move over one another . Cartilage is a smooth layer that covers the end of bones moving over each other .
 Bones are held together at the joint by strong, fibrous tissues called /igaments . Fibrous tissues attach above and below the joint to hold the bones together .
 Pivot joints, such as those found in the elbow, permit a rotating kind of movement . The elbow joint is one of the most important joints in the world .
 Ball-and-socket joints, like the shoulder, provide swinging and rotating movements like a collar to keep the joint in place . Ball and socket joints provide swinging movements like those of the shoulder .
 A sprain occurs when the ligaments around a joint are torn or badly stretched . The sprain is a sprain when ligaments are torn, stretched or torn . The injury occurs when a joint joint is torn or stretched .
 Serious sprains are painful, and if neglected may result in instability of the joint . If neglected, they may also lead to instability in the joint joint .
 Dislocated joints should be treated as soon as possible by a physician . Dislocate joints are a sign of life for a person with dislocated joints .
 Inflammation of the joints may result from infections or from such disorders as arthritis . Inflammated joints may also be caused by infections, such as arthritis or infections .
 Joint Chiefs of Staff is the highest military advisory group in the United States . Joint Chiefs are the highest-military advisory group .
 The chairman of the JCS is the principal military adviser to the U.S. president, the secretary of defense, and the National Security Council . He is also the principal Military Adviser to the United States president .
 Other members include the chiefs of staff of the Army and Air Force, the chief of naval operations, the commandant of the Marine Corps, and the vice chairman of the Joint Force .
 Joint Chiefs prepare military plans and review overall military requirements . Joint Chiefs review military plans for the first time . Joint chiefs also review overall requirements for the military .
 They represent the United States on military committees of international organizations . The U.S. military has been involved in more than 50 wars since 2001 .
 They direct the unified and specified combatant commands under the secretary of defense . They also direct the . unified . and specified . combatant commandant commands . The U.S. military says it is committed to the United States .
 The chairman regularly reviews these commands and makes appropriate recommendations to the president . The chairman of the National Security Council regularly reviews them .
 It includes directorates of personnel, intelligence, operations, logistics, plans and policy, and communications-electronics . The U.S. military is the largest military organization in the world .
 Previously, the commandant had been only a member only when the JCS discussed Marine Corps matters . The commandant is now a member of the Joint Joint Service Committee .
 In 1986, Congress strengthened the chairman's position and added the vice chairman position . The vice chairman was added to the chairman in 1986 .
 Joint-stock company was a form of business organization in which the funds to carry on business were obtained by selling shares of stock to a number of individuals . Joel Slackman was the founder of the first joint stock company .

 Joint tenancy is the ownership of a piece of property by two or more people . Joint tenancy involves ownership of pieces of property owned by two people .
 Each owner has equal rights to the use of the property during their lives . Each owner is entitled to use the property in their lifetime .
 The last survivor becomes the sole and exclusive owner of the property . He has the absolute right to sell or give it to anyone .
 Joint tenancies were once limited to real estate, but today they may be created in personal property as well . Joint tenancy is no longer limited to the real estate market .
 Two or more people might own a painting as joint tenants with the right of survivorship . For example, a painting might be owned by a group of people .
 The right of survivorship distinguishes a joint tenancy from the ordinary tenancy in common . The right to survivorship distinguish between the two types of tenancy . A joint tenancy differs from a common tenancy .
 Each tenant's share passes to his or her successors at the death of the tenant . Under a tenancy in common, each tenant's shares pass to his successor at death of tenant .
 While living, a joint tenant can convey the share in the joint-tenancy property to another person . Joint tenants can convey their share in a joint tenancy to another .
 In the United States, a few states do not recognize the joint tenancy of real estate . In the U.S., real estate is a joint tenancy, not a joint residence .
 Joel C Dobris Jojoba, hoh HOH buh, is an evergreen shrub that grows wild in desert regions of northwestern Mexico and southwestern United States .
 In 1971, the United States government banned whaling and the import of whale products . The U.S. government banned the practice of whaling .
 As a result of the ban, jojoba oil has become a valuable substitute for sperm whale oil in lubricants, cosmetics and many industrial chemicals .
 Joliot-Curte, zhaw LYOH koo REE, trene, ee REHN , was a French physicist . She was known for her work with radioactivity, especially the production of radioactive elements .
 She was the daughter of the Nobel Prize-winning physicists Marie and Pierre Curie . She was born in 1944 and died in 1944 .
 JoliotCurie and her husband, Frédéric, shared the 1935 Nobel Prize for chemistry . Joliot Curie and husband shared the prize .
 Joliot-Curies determined conditions under which positrons could be emitted when high-energy radioactive particles passed through matter . In 1933, the Joliot Curies determined the conditions under . which positron were emitted .
 In 1934, they demonstrated that the bombardment of boron by alpha particles created a radioactive isotope of nitrogen . The bombarded with borson created a nuclear isotope .
 The discovery led to the production of artificial radioactive elements . This led to their being awarded the Nobel Prize for their discovery .

 Romualdas Sviedrys Jolliet, /OH lee eht, Louis, /wee , also spelled /oliet, was a French-Canadian explorer who led an expedition down the Mississippi River .
 He and Jacques Marquette were probably — the first white explorers to reach the upper Mississippi and parts of Illinois and Wisconsin . He and Marquette, a French missionary, were probably .
 From 1669 to 1671, Jolliet explored much of the Great Lakes region for the government of New France . He explored New France's Great Lakes for government purposes .
 During this time, he became a skilled mapmaker and also worked as a fur trader . He also became skilled mapmakers .
 About 1670, Jolliet established a fur-trading post at Sault Sainte Marie in what is now Ontario, Canada . The post was established in 1670 and is now in Ontario .
 He traded guns, knives, and other items to Indian trappers in exchange for beaver pelts . The pelts brought great profits in France for the French .
 The Indians of the Great Lakes region often talked about a great waterway that flowed to the sea . The Indians believed it was a great river that flowed into the sea.
 They called it the Mississippi, which in their language meant big river . In their language, they called it Mississippi, meaning "big river"
 The French thought this river might flow west to the Pacific Ocean and provide a trading route to the Far East . The French believed this river would flow west and provide trade routes .
 In 1673, Governor General Comte de Frontenac of New France sent Jolliet to find the Mississippi and trace its course . The Governor General sent him to find and trace the Mississippi .
 Jesuit priest Marquette, a Jesuit priest, was chosen to accompany Jolliet . Marquette worked among the Indians as a missionary and knew their languages . He knew the Indians' languages .
 In May 1673, Jolliet and Marquette set out in two canoes from St. Louis . Marquette and five other men set out on their way to the city .
 When the group reached the mouth of the Arkansas River, they began to encounter unfriendly Indians . The group encountered the river mouth of Arkansas River .
 A friendly Indian told Marquette that white people lived farther south on the Mississippi . Marquette: "White people live farther south of the Mississippi"
 Jolliet and Marquette assumed these people must be Spaniards who had settled near the Gulf of Mexico . Marquette thought they were Spaniards living in the area .
 Fearing attacks by the Indians and the Spaniards, the party turned back . Fears attacks by Indians and Spaniards led the party to turn back .
 His maps and records of the journey were lost when he crossed the St. Lawrence River near Montreal, Canada .
 The government of New France gave Jolliet Anticosti Island in the Gulf of St. St. Louis .
 He traveled up into Hudson Bay in 1679 and explored Labrador in 1689 and 1694 . He explored the coast of present-day Labrador .
 In 1697, he was appointed hydrographer of the king with headquarters in Quebec . He was given the title in 1697 .

 Jordan is an Arab kingdom on the East Bank of the Jordan River in the heart of the Middle East . It is one of the largest Arab countries in the world .
 The country is bordered by Syria, Iraq; Iraq; Saudi Arabia; Israel; and the West Bank . The West Bank is west of the Jordan River .
 Much of Jordan's modern history has been shaped by events in an area often called Palestine . Jordan has been ruled by Jordan's rulers since 1948 . The region is often referred to as Palestine, and Jordan is now Jordan .
 Israel, the West Bank, and the tiny Gaza Strip cover this region . Israel, West Bank and the Gaza Strip are all part of the Israeli-West Bank region .
 Jordan was once called 7ransjordan because it lay across the Jordan River from Palestine . Jordan once lay on the edge of the Jordan river .

 In 1974, Jordan officially gave up political responsibility for the West Bank . Jordan gave up responsibility for West Bank in 1974 .
 Jordan continued to play important roles in the administration and financial support of the West Bank . But Jordan has continued to support the Palestinian government .
 In 1988, King Hussein of Jordan broke Jordan's ties with the West Bank . Jordan broke the ties with West Bank in 1988 .

 The Jordan River Valley is a deep, narrow valley that extends from the Sea of Galilee to the Dead Sea . It is one of the largest valleys in the world, stretching from south of the sea to south of Jordan .
 Jordan River flows through the center of the valley and ends in the Dead Sea . The Jordan River is the source of the Jordan River .
 Jordan River Valley is part of the Great Rift Valley, a deep cut in the earth's surface . The Jordan Valley Valley is the largest valley in the world's history .
 The Transjordan Plateau rises steeply from the Jordan River Valley and the Dead Sea . It is the tallest mountain in the world, rising from the top of the country's highest mountains .
 The plateau covers a wedge-shaped area that begins at the Syrian border and narrows as it extends southward to the region around Maan . The area is also known as Maan, which borders Syria and Syria .
 It consists of broad, rolling plains that have an average elevation of about 3,000 feet above sea level . The plains are covered in rolling plains with an average altitude of 3,500 feet .
 The plateau includes Jordan's largest cities and most of the country’s farmland . The plateau is Jordan's most populated area and is home to the largest cities in Jordan .
 Rainfall on the southern plateau is less dependable and averages between 10 and 15 inches a year . Rainfall is barely enough to grow wheat in the region .
 Average temperatures range between 64 and 86 °F during the summer and between 40 and 52 °F in the winter . Average temperatures are 64 to 86°F during summer and up to 52°F in winter .
 The Syrian Desert, also called the northern Arabian Desert, is a vast wasteland to the east and south of the plateau . It is also known as the Arabian Desert .
 The desert receives less than 10 inches (25 centimeters) of rain annually . The desert is home to the largest population in the world .

 Written history first mentions what is now Jordan in about 2000 B.C., when Semitic nomads entered the region . The region was populated by nomadic nomads in the early 2000s .
 Ammonites, Amorites, Edomites, and Moabites traded in lands east of the Jordan River . By about 1200 B.C., four Semitic peoples had been farming and trading east of Jordan River lands .
 During the 900's B.C. Israelites under Kings David and Solomon conquered and ruled the region . The Israelites conquered the region and ruled it for over a century .
 Later, the Egyptians, Assyrians, Chaldeans, and Persians invaded and controlled the area . The Egyptians and Assyrians also invaded the area and controlled it .
 The Nabataeans ruled from their unique capital city carved out of the rose-colored stone cliffs of Petra . The city was carved from the walls of Petra and ruled from its capital city .
 After his death, the Seleucids ruled the northern part of present-day Jordan . The Nabataeans ruled the southern part of the country .
 Jordan became part of the Byzantine Empire when the Roman Empire split in the late 300’s A.D. Jordan was part of East Roman Empire . Jordan was one of the most important sites in the Roman empire .
 Arab Muslims from the Arabian Peninsula defeated Byzantine armies in the northern Jordan region in 636 . In 636, Arab Muslims defeated Byzantine forces in the north Jordan region .
 The conquering Arabs established their language and religion among the people who lived in the region . The conquering Arab rulers established their religion among those who lived there . The conquerors of the region are known as the Arabs .
 They developed an important route through Jordan for Islamic pilgrimages to Mecca . The route was important route for Islamic pilgrims to Mecca.
 At the close of the 1000's, Christian crusaders from Europe conquered the eastern Mediterranean coast, including Jerusalem and parts of Jordan .
 The region had great religious significance for both Christians and Muslims . The region was known for its religious significance as a Christian-Muslim enclave .
 In 1517, the Ottoman Empire easily defeated the Mamelukes, and most of Jordan became part of it . Most of Jordan was part of the Ottoman empire until 1517 . The Ottoman Empire ruled most of the region .
 During Ottoman rule, the region's only attraction for outsiders was the pilgrimage route . The region was largely uninhabited during the Ottoman rule .
 The Ottomans did not govern Jordan directly until the late 1800's . Circassian families settled in and near Amman, Jordan .
 In 1908, a railway was completed along the pilgrimage route, stimulating Jordan’s economy . The railway was built in 1908, stimulating the country's economy .
 Sharif Hussein of Mecca in Saudi Arabia led an Arab revolt against Ottoman rule . During World War . Hussein led the Arab revolt . He led the revolt against the Ottoman Empire .
 The revolt led to the defeat of the Ottomans in the Middle East and the establishment of several Arab states . With the help of the United Kingdom, the revolt ended the Ottoman rule of the region . The revolt was the first Arab revolt since the fall of the Ottoman Empire .
 In 1921, the British gave the territory east of the Jordan partial self-government by making it an emirate called Transjordan . In 1921 the British made the territory part of the Trans-Jordan emirates .

 James Kirby Martin Joule is a unit in the metric system of measurement . It is used to measure work or energy, and is used in a metric system . Joule, joo/ or jow, is a measurement unit used in metric systems .
 The joule is used to measure all forms of energy, including heat, electrical energy, and mechanical energy . It is used in the study of all types of energy .
 A calorie is the amount of energy needed to raise the temperature of 1 gram of water by 1 Celsius degree . A calorie can be found in a small amount of water .
 One joule of energy per second is required to pass an electric current of 1 ampere through 1 ohm resistance . The current is 1 ampere through the resistance of a 1-second electric current . The energy is needed to pass a current of one am
 In the inch-pound system of measurement customarily used in the United States, work or energy is measured in foot-pounds . In the U.S., energy is defined as work or work in a foot pound .
 Hugh D Young Joule, joo/ or jow/, helped prove the law of conservation of energy . James Prescott, a British physicist, proved the law .
 This law states that energy is neither created nor destroyed when it changes from one form to another . This law also says that energy can be created and destroyed in one form .
 Joule’s experiments demonstrated that energy seemingly lost is actually converted into heat . Joule: ‘Energy seemed lost but actually converted to heat.’
 His results supported the theories of German physicists Hermann von Helmholtz and Julius Robert von Mayer, and British physicist Lord Kelvin, and Lord Kelvin .
 Joule discovered a mathematical relationship between the energy of an electric current and the amount of heat produced by that current . In 1840, Joule found a relationship between a current's energy and heat produced from it . Joule was the inventor of the Joule Theory .
 In 1847, he announced the discovery of a similar relationship between mechanical energy and heat . The discovery of mechanical energy was also announced in 1847 .

 Free nations grant the press freedom to report news and opinions without government interference . The U.S. government should not interfere with press freedom, says CNN.com .
 Freedom of the press encourages the exchange of ideas among citizens, which is essential for a democracy to work . Freedom of press is essential to a democracy, says Julian Zelizer .
 In government-controlled societies, the news media presents chiefly news that supports the policies of the government . In government controlled societies, however, news media often supports the government's policies .

 A paper must be printed and distributed before it can bring a story to the public . The public must see the content of this article .

 The rest of the press relies chiefly on news services for national and international news . This is the only major news service to rely on .
 Their stories, as well as photographs, are transmitted mainly by satellite to members of the press that pay for the service . Their stories are transmitted by satellite .

 The major news syndicates are owned by newspapers that have a large staff of reporters at home and abroad . The syndicates include major news organizations with large staffs of reporters .
 The syndicate distributes to its clients many of the same stories that appear in its own paper . It distributes many of its own stories to its own clients .
 Feature syndicates are operated by business organizations that sell material such as advice columns, comic strips, and opinion columns . Feature syndicate is operated by businesses that sell such material . Features syndicates include advice columns and comic strips .
 Magazines, like newspapers, enable people to absorb the news at their own pace and select only the stories that interest them . Magazines are like newspapers and people can choose only stories they want to hear .

 These duties include informing the public, investigating wrongdoing, influencing public opinion, and entertaining the public . These duties also include investigating wrongdoing .

 In general, newspapers and magazines in free societies are privately owned . In free societies, they are often owned privately .
