 History The first newspapers were probably handwritten newssheets that governments posted in public places . The first newspaper was probably handwritten .
 The Roman Senate reported the proceedings of the Roman Senate and such news such as births and deaths . It also reported such news as births, deaths and births .
 The first regularly published printed newspaper in Europe was Avisa Relation oder Zeitung of Strasbourg, Germany . The first regular published newspaper was a weekly newspaper in Germany .
 A weekly newssheet founded in 1622 was the first paper regularly printed in England . It was first to be published in England and was first newspaper to be printed regularly .
 Early newspaper publishers had to obtain a government license for anything they wanted to print . Early newspapers had to get a license from the government .
 In 1644, the English poet and political writer John Milton criticized licensing in his pamphlet Areopagitica . Milton criticized such licensing in 1644 .
 England lifted its licensing system in 1695, and several other countries ended theirs in the 1700's . Several other countries also ended their licensing system .
 Many countries tried to limit the number of people who could afford to publish newspapers by making them pay a heavy tax on each page they printed .
 As a result, publishers made their pages as large as possible to print more material for the same tax . Publishers printed more pages to print for the tax .
 By the 1800's, however, these taxes had been ended, and the press in many countries had considerable freedom . By the 18th century, the freedom of the press had been greatly reduced .
 Before the 1700's, the American colonists relied on pamphlets, handwritten newsletters, English newspapers, and town criers for the news . The American colonists used pamphlets and English newspapers for news .
 In 1690, Benjamin Harris of Boston founded Publick Occurrences Both Forreign and Domestick . Harris was the first newspaper published in America . Harris published the newspaper in 1690 .
 In 1704, John Campbell established the Boston News-Letter, the first regularly published paper in the colonies . The paper was established by Campbell in 1704 .
 John Peter Zenger founded the New-York Weekly Journal in 1733 . He soon won a victory for a free press .
 The governor's council had Zenger arrested, and in 1735 he was tried for libel . Zenger was found guilty of libel and tried for his libel .
 The jury found Zenger not guilty after his attorney argued that Zenger had printed the truth and that truth is not libelous . Zenger was found not guilty of libelous libel after a jury found him not guilty .
 The act required that special tax stamps be placed on all newspapers, legal documents, and various other written material . Special stamps were placed on newspapers and legal documents . The stamps were required by the act .
 Newspapers continued to publish without buying the stamps, and they supported the colonists . Newspapers published without buying stamps and continued to do so .
 They also sold for about 6 cents a copy— far more than working-class people could afford . The books sold for around 6 cents per copy . They sold for far less than 6 cents .
 The Sun attracted a large audience because of its low cost and its lively reports of fires, crimes, marriages, and other humaninterest news . The Sun's low cost was due to its low-cost and lively reports .
 In addition to reporting the news, the 7ribune published book reviews and poetry . It also ran editorials opposing slavery and supporting women’s rights .
 Other penny papers included the Philadelphia Public Ledger, the Baltimore Sun, and the Boston Daily Times .
 The newspapers shared the cost of receiving news from telegraph agents throughout the nation and sold the reports to other papers . The newspapers sold the news to each other .
 In the 1850's, papers from such cities as Boston, Chicago, Philadelphia, and St. Louis were published in the papers of the day .
 The age of sensationalism lasted from the late 1800's to the early 1900's . The age was known as sensationalism in the early 1800's .
 American newspapers increasingly emphasized stories that dealt with crimes, disasters, and scandals . During this period, American newspapers emphasized stories dealing with crimes and disasters .
 At the same time, however, the papers started reform campaigns by hunting out and exposing corruption in business and government . The papers also exposed corruption in government and business .
 Magazines also began printing articles by reform writers, including Samuel Hopkins Adams, Lincoln Steffens and Ida M Tarbell .
 These two papers became strong rivals in the battle for readers and led the press in sensationalism .
 The competition for readers sometimes resulted in inacTT curate, exaggerated reporting that came to be known as yellow journalism . The competition also resulted in exaggerated reporting .
 Another important publisher of the time, Edward WyIlis Scripps, established the first American newspaper chain . The first newspaper chain was established by the same publisher . The company was founded in 1881 .

 Radio journalism began in the United States in 1920, when station KDKA in Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania, broadcast the presidential election returns . Station KDKA broadcast election returns in 1920 .
 During the 1920's, coverage of political and sports events became the most important type of public affairs broadcasting . Coverage of political, sports events was the most significant type of broadcasting .
 Many regular news programs consisted merely of an announcer who read stories from newspapers or wire services . Today's news programs often consisted of news stories read by an announcer .

 The programs in the series consisted of on-the-scene reports dealing with leading issues of the day . The programs were intended to be on the front foot of the story .

 A nationwide audience watched as the men faced each other in the first televised presidential debates between presidential candidates . The debates were televised for the first time .

 Major improvements in broadcast technology continued during the 1970's . Major improvements were made in the 1970s .
 Development of minicams made videotape practical for use on daily newscasts . Minicams were developed in the 1950s and '60s .
 A story taped with a minicam can be broadcast minutes after a reporter delivers the tape to the TV station . A minicamer can be used to record a story that can be shown to a TV station later that night .
 Minicams are often used with specially equipped mobile vans that can relay a story to the station as it happens . In addition to minicams, the vans can also be used to relay stories to CNN .
 By the late 1990's, the communications satellite had become an important tool of journalism . The communications satellite was used to provide vital information to journalists .
 A communications satellite orbits the earth and relays radio, telegraph, telephone, and television signals . It relays signals from the earth .
 Communications satellites help journalists gather information and distribute news reports . Communications satellites are used to gather information for journalists .
 Television journalists can instantly report news events to their TV stations thousands of miles away . They also enable television journalists to instantly report events to TV stations across the world . The technology allows them to do so in a matter of minutes .
 Many news services deliver reports to news organizations via communications satellite . Many news organizations deliver reports via communications satellites .

 Judaism, /OO dee ihz uhm, is the religion of the world’s approximately 15 million Jews . Judaism is a religion of around 15 million people .
 It is the oldest major religion and the first religion to teach the belief in one God . It is also the first major religion to believe in one god .
 Judaism is the religion of only one people -- the Jews . Unlike the other major religions, Judaism is only one of the world's major religions . Jews are the only people in the world .
 These religions accept the Jewish belief in one God and the moral teachings of the Hebrew Bible .
 The basic laws and teachings of Judaism come from the 7orah, the first five books of the Hebrew Bible . The 7orah is the name of the first book of the Bible .

 Judaism teaches that all people are created in the image of God and deserve to be treated with dignity and respect .
 Moral and ethical teachings are as important in Judaism as teachings about God . Thus, moral and ethical teaching is as important as God's teachings .

 These laws explained how the Israelites should live their lives and build their community . Israelites were taught how to live in order to build a community .

 Talmud is a collection of legal, ritual, and ethical writings, as well as Jewish history and folklore . The Talmud was written by Jewish scholars and rabbis .
 It serves primarily as a guide to the civil and religious laws of Judaism . It is published by Jewish Publicationism Institute for Jewish Studies .
 Orthodox Jews believe the laws in the Talmud were an oral Torah,” which God gave Moses as an explanation of the written Torah . The Talmud was an explanation for Moses, according to Orthodox Jews .
 About A.D. 200, scholars wrote down these oral laws in a work called the Mishnah . Later scholars interpreted the work and interpreted it . The Mishnah is a work written by Jewish scholars .

 They strictly observe all traditional Jewish laws, including dietary rules and the laws for keeping the Sabbath .

 The structure of Judaism Judaism has no one person as its head and no international body with authority over religious practices . Judaism is not a single person in charge of religious matters .
 Each local congregation chooses its own rabbi and manages its own affairs . Each congregation chooses their own rabbi .
 The synagogue is the Jewish house of worship and the center of Jewish education and community activities . It is a Jewish home of worship, the synagogue is also a center for Jewish education .
 It may also include a school where children study Judaism, the Hebrew language, and Jewish history . The school may also be a school for children studying Judaism .
 Most synagogues are constructed so that the worshipers face toward the holy city of Jerusalem during the service . The service is held in front of Jerusalem .
 At the front of the sanctuary stands the ark, a chest in which the scrolls of the Torah are kept . The ark is the chest where the Torah scrolls are kept and is kept .
 In front of the ark hangs the eternal light, an oil lamp whose constant flame symbolizes God's eternal presence . The oil lamp symbolizes the presence of God, a constant flame .

 Most rabbinical students also study a wide range of nonreligious subjects . Rabbinical students often study nonreligious topics .

 Judicial review in the broadest sense refers to the power of a court to strike down any legislative or executive action that it finds in violation of a nation’s constitution or other law . Judicial review is a federal court's power to review any legislation or actions that the court finds in
 Judicial review refers to a court's power to declare laws unconstitutional . In its narrowest sense, it refers to the power of a court to declare a law unconstitutional .
 A court would find that the law violates freedom of speech set forth in the First Amendment of the Constitution . For example, if the United States Congress were to pass a law forbidding criticism of public officials, the law would violate First Amendment rights .
 By invalidating the law, the court would be exercising the power of judicial review . The law would be invalidated by the court, the judge says . The case would be the first time the law has been invalidated .
 Constitutional democracies worldwide accept the judicial review process . Constitutional democracies around the world accept the process of judicial review .
 Most constitutions written since World War II specifically provide for some form of judicial review . The Supreme Court is expected to address the issue in the next year .
 The case marked the first time the Supreme Court declared an act of Congress unconstitutional . The case was declared unconstitutional by the justices .
 Chief Justice John Marshall reasoned that the judicial branch must have the authority to issue authoritative interpretations of the Constitution . Marshall: The judicial branch can decide whether an act of the legislative branch violates the Constitution; and to declare any such act unconstitutional . Chief Justice Marshall: "The judicial branch has the
 Many cases of judicial review resemble the Marbury case itself, in that courts specifically determine a law's consistency with a nation’s constitution . Courts specifically determine the consistency with the constitution .
 In other cases, courts determine the validity of rules and regulations made by executive agencies . Courts also decide whether to enforce rules and rules made by the government .
 In complex areas such as tax law and environmental protection, legislators lack time or technical expertise to legislate every detail of the necessary rules . In such complex areas, legislators may lack the time or the technical expertise for such complex laws .
 Governments often call upon expert agencies, such as the Internal Revenue Service, to develop and enforce detailed rules and regulations .
 Judicial review ensures agencies stay within the boundaries set by the relevant legislation . Judicial review in this context ensures that agencies stay in line with legislation .
 Judicial review ensures that a nation’s constitution and other laws are honored not just in theory but also in practice . When used properly, judicial review can be used to protect the constitution, not only in theory .
 If courts exercise this power too aggressively, they may interfere with lawmaking processes reserved for elected legislators, or with regulatory functions assigned to expert executive agencies .  Jugular vein, /UHG yuh yuh /uhr, is the name of each of four large veins that return blood to the heart from the head and neck . The name of the vein is each of the four large large veins .
 The veins get their name from the Latin word jugulus, which means collarbone . The veins are called jugulus and jugulus in Latin .
 There are two jugular veins on each side of the neck, known as the external and internal jugulars . The internal and external jugular's are known as internal or external .
 The external jugulars lie close to the surface and carry blood from the outside parts of the head and neck to the heart . The external jointulars carry blood from  the outside of the head and neck to the heart.
 The internal jugulars lie deeper and carry blood from the deeper tissues of the neck and from the interior of the skull . The internal blood vessels lie deeper in the internal neck and the internal skull .
 The internal jugular veins are much larger than the external jugular vein . Internal veins are the ones commonly referred to as internal . The internal veins are larger than external ones .
 Opening an internal jugular vein usually proves fatal, because of the rapid loss of blood . Opening an open internal vein often proves fatal because of rapid blood loss .

 The movements of a jumping bean are actually caused by a caterpillar that lives inside the seed . The movements are caused by the caterpillar inside the bean seed .

 The caterpillar eats away the inside of the seed, but it leaves the seed wall undamaged . The seed wall is left unharmed by the caterpillar .

 The adult moth pushes through the lid and leaves the seed . When the change is completed, the adult moth will push into the lid .

 Jung, yoong, Carl Gustav , was a Swiss psychiatrist and psychologist . He developed the field of analytical psychology . Jung was the founder of the Jung Jung Society .
 His teachings extended beyond psychology and influenced other fields, including anthropology, philosophy, and theology . His teachings included anthropology and philosophy .
 Jung challenged many of the theories proposed by the famous Austrian physician Sigmund Freud, who had developed the method of therapy called psychoanalysis . Jung challenged Freud's theories in his work .
 Jung and Freud stressed the effects of unconscious ideas on human behavior . However, both Freud and Jung stressed the effect unconscious ideas had on human behaviour .

 Jung, a ministers son, was born on July 26, 1875, in Kesswil, Switzerland . Jung was born in 1875 and was a minister's son .
 As a boy, he developed a lifelong interest in superstition, mythology, and the occult . As a child, he became fascinated with superstition and mythology .
 Jung participated in the psychoanalytic movement . Jung and Jung were close friends and became close friends .
 Freud believed Freud placed too much importance on sexual instincts in human behavior . Jung believed Freud had put too much emphasis on sexual instinct in his work . Freud's work was published in 1900s The Life and The Life of Love .
 Jung's de-emphasis of sexuality led to a break with Freud, and their friendship ended in 1913 . Jung's relationship with Freud ended after a close friendship with him .
 Extroverts seek the company of other individuals for personal fulfillmentment . Extrovert seeks the companionship of others for personal fulfillment . Extromoteness is a self-confessed introvert .
 Jung taught that therapists should help patients balance the two character types in themselves . Jung taught patients to balance their character types with themselves .
 He believed personalities of parents are major influences on a child . He believed the personalities of a child were major influences .
 Jung taught that sexuality does not become important until just before young people reach puberty . Unlike Freud, Jung taught sexuality does become important only before puberty . Jung: Sexuality is important only for young people to reach puberty, not just before puberty.
 Jung believed that the unconscious part of the mind contains personal drives and experiences of which an individual is not aware . Jung, like Freud, believed that an individual's personal drives were not aware of . Jung said that unconscious drives and personal experiences are personal drives .
 Jung also thought that members of every race share a deeper level of unconsciousness, which he called the co/lective unconscious . Jung thought that the members of all races share a deep level of consciousness .
 Jung says the collective unconscious includes thought patterns called archetypes, which have developed through the centuries . Jung says archetypes are thought patterns that have developed throughout the world . Jung: Archetypes are a pattern pattern that has developed through centuries .

 Junior Achievement is an organization that educates young people about business and economics . Junior Achievement teaches students about business, economics and business .
 The organization operates in cities, suburbs, and rural areas across the United States . Business and industrial firms sponsor the organization, which operates across the country .
 Junior Achievement conducts activities that begin in kindergarten and continue through high school . Activities include classroom programs, after-school programs, and Internet exercises .
 Junior Achievement programs are taught by classroom volunteers from the business community . Junior Achievement is a Junior Achievement program taught by students from the community .
 In the Junior Achievement Company Program, high school students form, manage, and operate their own companies during the school year . The program is an atter-school program that teaches students how to form and manage their own businesses .
 They keep records, pay themselves small wages, and run their businesses . They also run their own small businesses .
 At the end of the school year, the students dissolve their corporations and divide their capital and any profit among shareholders . Students divide capital and profits among shareholders at end of school year . Students dissolve corporations and split their profits .

 Hall of Fame honors people who have made outstanding contributions to American business . The hall of fame is based in New York City .
 Junior Achievement was founded in Springfield, Massachusetts, in 1919 by Theodore N Vail, president of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company, Horace A Moses, a paper manufacturer, and Senator Winthrop Murray Crane .
 Junior high school is a school designed mainly for students in the seventh, eighth, and ninth grades . The school is designed for seventh and eighth grade students .
 Some junior high schools consist of only grades seven and eight . However, some schools have only grades 7 and 8 instead of grades 7-8 .
 The purpose of a junior high school is to help boys and girls from 12 to 15 years of age prepare for high school . Boys and girls 12-15 years old will attend the school . The school's purpose is to prepare them for the transition to high school.
 During these years, most young people begin to undergo the physical, mental, social, and emotional changes associated with adolescence . During this period, most people undergo physical and mental changes . This is when they begin to experience the physical and social, social and emotional effects of adolescence .

 In this way, the junior high school is more like a high school than an elementary school . "In this way," the school's principal says . "I'm not going to let it be a school that's not a school," he says .

 At the same time, they begin studying subjects that were once only taught only in high school .

 These are courses chosen from a variety of nonrequired subjects, such as business education or music . The courses chosen are chosen from non-required subjects .

 Jupiter is a giant ball of gas and liquid with little, if any, solid surface . Jupiter is also known as the largest planet in the solar system system .
 The planet's surface is composed of dense red, brown, yellow, and white clouds . It is not the surface of the planet, but the surface is covered in clouds .
 The clouds are arranged in light-colored areas called zones and darker regions called be/ts . They circle the planet parallel to the equator . The clouds cover the planet's equator and circle the globe .
 The planet completes one orbit in 4,333 Earth-days, or almost 12 Earthyears . It is the first planet to orbit the Earth in 12 Earth years .
 As Jupiter orbits the sun, the planet rotates on its avis, an imaginary line through its center . The line is a line through the center of the planet's center .
 Scientists measure tilt relative to a line at a right angle to the orbital plane . An imaginary surface touching all points of the orbit touches all points in the orbit of the Earth .
 It takes 9 hours 55 minutes to spin around once on the axis, compared to 24 hours for Earth . Earth spins around once every day, the fastest in the world's history .
 Scientists cannot measure the rotation of the interior of the giant planet directly, so they have calculated the speed from indirect measurements .
 The speed was calculated using an average of the speeds of the clouds that move with interior currents, except for a more rapid zone near the equator .
 Jupiter sends out radio waves strong enough to be picked up by radio telescopes on Earth . Jupiter's radio waves can be detected by telescopes in Earth's telescopes .
 Scientists now measure these waves to calculate Jupiter's rotational speed . The waves will be used to calculate the planet's rotation speed .
 The strength of the waves varies under the influence of Jupiter's magnetic field in a pattern that repeats every 9 hours 55 minutes . The waves are waves that vary under the magnetic field .
 Jupiter's magnetic field Originates in Jupiter's core . This variation shows how fast the plants interior spins .
 Jupiter's rapid rotation makes it bulge at the equator and flatten at the poles . It bulges at its poles, flattens at the polar poles . Jupiter is one of the largest solar systems in the solar system .
 The planet's diameter is about 6 percent larger at the equator than at the poles . The diameter of the planet is also 6 percent bigger at the polar poles .
 Its density averages 1.33 grams per cubic centimeter, slightly more than the density of water . The density of the water is slightly higher than water .
 The density of Jupiter is about 1 that of Jet Propulsion Laboratory . The layers of dense clouds around Jupiter appear in a photograph of the planet taken by Voyager 1 space probe .
 Jupiter's low density means it consists of hydrogen and helium, the lightest elements . Astronomers believe that the planet is primarily made up of hydrogen, helium .
 Jupiter's mix of chemical elements resembles that of the sun, rather than that of Earth . Jupiter is one of the most powerful solar systems in the solar system system .
 The core may be of about the same chemical composition as Earth, but 20 or 30 times more massive . Core may be 20 to 30 times larger than Earth, according to scientists . Core is of the same composition as the Earth .
 The force of gravity at the surface of Jupiter is up to 2.5 times stronger than on Earth . Jupiter's gravity is 2.2 times stronger on the surface than on the Earth .
 The atmosphere of Jupiter is composed of 86 percent hydrogen, 14 percent helium, and tiny amounts of methane, ammonia, phosphine, water, acetylene, ethane, germanium, and carbon monoxide .
 The percentage of hydrogen is based on the number of hydrogen molecules in the atmosphere, rather than on their total mass . It's based on a percentage of the hydrogen molecules that are in the Earth's atmosphere, not their mass .
 Scientists have calculated these amounts from measurements taken with telescopes and other instruments on Earth and aboard spacecraft . Scientists calculate these amounts using measurements taken from telescopes, other instruments and spacecraft .
 These chemicals have formed colorful layers of clouds at different heights . The clouds were formed by chemicals used to create clouds .

 Most astronomers believe that the sun, the planets, and all the other bodies in the solar system formed from a spinning cloud of gas and dust . Most astronomers say the sun and planets formed from spinning clouds .
 The gravitation of the gas and dust particles packed them together into dense clouds and solid chunks of material . The gravity of the clouds packed the particles together .
 By about 4. billion years ago, the material had squeezed together to form the various bodies in the solar system . The material squeezed together into the different solar systems .
 So much heat was produced when Jupiter formed that the planet still radiates about twice as much heat into space as it receives from sunlight . Jupiter still receives about twice the same amount of heat from sunlight as it does from light .
 The force of its magnetism extends far into space in a region surrounding the planet called its magnetic field . This region is called the magnetic field and is called a region around the planet .
 Jupiter's magnetic field is about 14 times as strong as Earth's, according to measurements made by spacecraft . Jupiter has a magnetic field that is 14 times stronger than Earth's .
 Jupiter's magnetic field is the strongest in the solar system, except for fields associated with sunspots and other small regions on the sun's surface . Jupiter has the strongest magnetic field in solar system .
 Scientists do not fully understand how planets produce magnetic fields . Scientists say magnetic fields are key to understanding how planets make magnetic waves .
 The scientists suspect that electrically charged particles in the interior of planets generate the fields . They suspect that the movement of electrically . charged particles may also generate the field .
 Jupiter's field would be so much stronger than Earth's because of its greater size and faster rotation . Jupiter's greater size means it has a stronger field than the Earth's due to its size .
 Jupiter's magnetic field traps electrons, protons, and other electrically charged particles in radiation belts around the planet . Jupiter has a magnetic field that traps electrons and protons around the world .
 The particles can damage instruments aboard spacecraft operating near the planet . The particles are so powerful that they can damage spacecraft instruments aboard .
 Within a region of space called the magnetosphere, Jupiter's magnetic field acts as a shield . Jupiter's magnetosphere is a part of the planet's magnetic zone .
 The field protects the planet from the so/ar wind, a continuous flow of charged particles from the sun . The field is also known as a shield protecting Earth from the solar wind .

 In March 1993, astronomers Eugene Shoemaker, Carolyn Shoemaker and David H Levy discovered a comet near Jupiter . The impact of Comet ShoemakerLevy 9 was the first comet to be discovered by astronomers .
 Shoemaker-Levy 9 was pulled by Jupiter's gravity into an orbit around the planet . The comet probably once orbited the sun independently but had been pulled by the planet's gravity .
 Calculations based on the comet's location and velocity showed that the fragments would crash into Jupiter's atmosphere in July 1994 .
 Scientists hoped to see much about the effects of a collision between a planet and a comet . Scientists hope to see how the Earth and the comet collided .
 Astronomers at all the major telescopes on Earth turned their instruments toward Jupiter at the predicted collision times . The collision times were predicted by astronomers at all major telescopes .
 Scientists also observed Jupiter with the Hubble Space Telescope, which is in orbit around Earth; and the remotely controlled space probe Galileo, which was on its way to Jupiter .
 The fragments fell on the back side of Jupiter as viewed from Earth and the Hubble Space Telescope . The fragments were captured by the Hubble telescope on Jupiter's back side .
 The rotation of Jupiter carried the sites around to the visible side after less than half an hour . But the rotation of the planet's rotation carried the impact sites around . The impact sites were not visible for more than an hour, according to Nasa .

 The impacts caused large explosions, probably due to the compression, heating, and rapid expansion of atmospheric gases . The impact of the impacts are thought to have been caused by large explosions . The impacts were probably caused by the compression and heating of the gases .
 The explosions scattered comet debris over large areas, some with diameters larger than that of Earth . Some of the debris was so large it was larger than the Earth .
 The debris gradually spread into a dark haze of fine material that remained suspended in Jupiter's upper atmosphere . It remained suspended for several months in the upper atmosphere of the planet .
 If a similar comet ever collided with Earth, it might produce a haze that would cool the atmosphere and darken the planet by absorbing sunlight . A similar comet could also darken Earth's atmosphere by absorbing light .
 If the haze lasted long enough, much of Earth's plant life could die, along with the people and animals that depend on plants . The haze could also kill the people, animals and people who depend on the plants .

 Pioneer 10 was launched in 1972 and flew within 81,000 miles of Jupiter on Dec., 1973 . Pioneer 10 launched in 1973 and flew to Jupiter in December, 1973 . It was the first time Pioneer 10 had flown to Jupiter .
 The probe revealed the severe effects of Jupiter's radiation belt on spacecraft . Probe revealed the effects of the radiation belt in the solar system .

 The probe discovered that Jupiter has an enormous magnetosphere . In addition to the probe, it also discovered that the planet has a huge magnetic field .
 Pioneer-Saturn flew within 27,000 miles (43,000 kilometers) of Jupiter in December 1974 . The probe was the first of its kind to fly within a direct orbit of Jupiter .
 The craft provided close-up photographs of Jupiter's polar regions and data on the Great Red Spot, the magnetic field, and atmospheric temperatures . The craft also provided data on Jupiter's magnetic field and atmospheric temperature .
 Voyager 1 and Voyager 2 flew past Jupiter in March and July 1979 . Voyager 2 and Voyager 1 flew past the planet in July 1979, respectively, respectively .
 These craft carried more sensitive instruments than did the Pioneers, and transmitted more information . These craft were more powerful and more reliable than their predecessors did .
 Astronomers used photos taken by the Voyagers to make the first detailed maps of the Galilean satellites . Astronomers also used photos of the satellites to map the Earth's satellites .
 Voyagers also revealed sulfur volcanoes on lo, discovered lightning in Jupiter's clouds, and mapped flow patterns in the cloud bands .
 Ulysses was launched in October 1990 and passed by Jupiter in February 1992 . It was the first spacecraft to pass by Jupiter .
 The European Space Agency had built the probe mainly to study the sun’s polar regions . The European space agency is an organization of Western European nations .
 Scientists used the tremendous gravitational force of Jupiter to put Ulysses into an orbit that would take it over the suns polar regions . The spacecraft will orbit the sun over the polar regions of the planet .
 The solar wind has a much greater effect on Jupiter's magnetosphere than earlier measurements had suggested . Ulysses passed by Jupiter, it gathered data indicating that the solar wind had a greater effect .
 Galileo’s mission was to measure the amount of water and other chemicals in Jupiter's atmosphere . One of Galileo's missions was to find water and chemicals in the atmosphere of the planet .
 Its first task was to record on tape the data transmitted by the probe, then relay the data to Earth . The probe's first task is to record the data .
 It then monitored Jupiter's atmosphere, and it observed the planet's major satellites . It also monitored the atmosphere of Jupiter, and observed the world's largest satellites .

 Jura, /OO ruh, is a mountain range that lies between the Rhine and Rhone rivers . It lies in the middle of the Rhone and Rhine .
 The highest peaks in the world are less than 6,000 feet (1,800 meters) above sea level . The highest peak is less than 1,800 feet (6,000 meters) away .
 Land on the middle and lower slopes of the range serves as pasture for the important dairy industry . Land in the lower slopes is pasture for dairy farmers in the region .

 Jute, joot, is along, soft, shiny fiber that can be spun into coarse, strong threads . Soft, shiny fibers are spun into fine threads . Jute is soft and shiny fiber .
 Natural fibers is second only to cotton in amount produced and variety of uses . It is one of the cheapest natural fibers in the world, and is second to cotton .
 Jute fibers are composed primarily of the plant materials cellulose, lignin, and pectin . The fibers are made from cellulose and lignins, which are used in fibers .
 Both the fiber and the plant from which it comes are commonly called jute . Jute is commonly known as jute, and the fiber is made of both fiber and plant .
 Jute is used chiefly to make cloth for wrapping bales of raw cotton, and to make gunny sacks and gunny cloth . Jute also used in gunny bags, gunners and gunners cloth .
 The fibers are woven into curtains, chair coverings, carpets, and burlap . The fibers also weave into curtains and chair covers .
 The fibers are used alone or blended with other types of fibers to make twine and rope . They can be used in twine or in rope .
 Jute butts, the coarse ends of the plants, are used to make inexpensive cloth . Jute Butts are used in inexpensive cloths .
 China, India, and Bangladesh rank as the world’s main producers of jute . Jute is a popular form of cloth used to make clothing and shoes .
 The fibers are off-white to brown and 3 to 15 feet (0. to 4. meters) long . They are pressed into bales for shipment to manufacturers . Jute fibers are 3-15 feet long and 3-5 feet long .

 The juvenile courts were to be places to help, not punish, children . According to these new attitudes, the juvenile courts should be places where children can be helped .

 Kansas is governed under its original Constitution, which was drawn up in 1859 . The state is governed by the original Constitution .
 Amendments must be approved by two-thirds of the members in each house of the Legislature, and by a majority of the voters . Amendments to the state's constitution must also be approved in advance of a majority vote .
 Such a convention may be called only with the approval of two-thirds of the legislators and a majority of the people who vote on the issue in a statewide election . The convention may only be called if the majority of those who vote for it call it .
 The Legislature must call an election to approve the convention's actions . The convention must also be called upon by the state legislature .
 They may be elected to an unlimited number of terms, but not more than two in a row . They can be re-elected to a maximum of three terms . They may not be elected as many as two terms, not as many times as three .
 Other top elected state officials include the secretary of state, attorney general, treasurer, and insurance commissioner of insurance .
 Each is elected to a four-year term, and may serve an unlimited number of terms . Each term is four years old, and each can serve a maximum of four years .

 Kansas became the first U.S. state to form a legislative council in 1933 . Kansas was the first state in the United States to form its own legislative council .
 This council, now known as a legislative coordinating council, consists of leaders of the state Senate and House of Representatives . This council is now called the Legislative Coordinating Council .

 Kansas gets more than half of its general revenue from state taxes . The government of Kansas gets over half of the state's general tax revenue .

 His work is influential because he established the main lines for philosophical developments since his day . His work was influential because of his work established the most lines of philosophical developments .
 Kant discussed the nature and limits of human knowledge in his chief work, Critique of Pure Reason . Kant's work is the work he wrote about the nature of knowledge .
 This question became important to him because of Scottish philosopher David Hume’s theories . This question was important because of David Hume's theories, he says .
 Before Hume, most philosophers assumed that our past experience could provide knowledge about matters that go beyond our experience . Hume assumed that past experience would provide knowledge beyond our own experience .
 Hume argued that we cannot be certain of anything beyond our experience . Hume said that we can't be certain that anything is beyond our own experience .
 The law of universal gravitation states that a force of attraction acts between all objects . For example, the law states that all objects in the universe are subject to a force that acts between them .
 Our experience is restricted to only a few objects that we have observed. But our experience has been limited to a handful of objects that have been observed. We are only able to observe a few of these objects.
 Kant believed we cannot justify claims beyond our actual experience as long as we continue to think of the mind and its objects as separate things . Kant believed that we cannot justified claims beyond the actual experience of our mind .
 He held instead that the mind is actively involved in the objects it experiences . The mind is active in the experiences it experiences, rather than passive observers .
 Experience organizes experience into categories, or forms of understanding . That is, it organizes experiences into categories of understanding, rather than categories .
 All things capable of being experienced are also arranged in these categories . The categories include things that can be experienced and can be easily experienced .
 Kant believed that we can have knowledge of what we have not yet experienced as well as what we've already experienced . Kant believed we can know what we already have and what we haven't experienced .
 Kant’ conclusions meant having to abandon any claim to know things as they are in themselves, things in which the mind is not involved, he said . Kant's conclusions were meant to abandon claims to be made by the mind as they were in themselves .
 He didn't deny the existence of things in themselves, which he called noumena . But he did not deny the fact that things are in themselves .
 Some philosophers regarded this refusal to claim absolute knowledge as too serious a limitation on a system of philosophy . Some philosophers thought it was a serious limitation on philosophy .
 Other philosophers argued that we have an intuitive, nonrational knowledge of things . Other philosophers have argued that people have intuitive knowledge of everything .
 He argued that the existence of God cannot be proved or disproved by the use of reason . He said that God's existence cannot be proven by using reason .
 Kant says reason is restricted to ideas of possible experience . The idea of God transcends all possible experience, Kant says . Kant says God transcates all possible experiences in the world .
 Kant held that faith could be rational because we cannot think of the world as orderly or justify our morality without supposing the existence of God . Kant said we cannot justify morality or justify morality without thinking about God without faith .
 In ethics, Kant tried to show that doing one’s duty consisted in following only those principles that one would accept as applying equally to all . Even assuming that scientists can predict what we are going to do, the predictions do not conflict with our use of free will .
 The predictions of scientists have no bearing on our duty to live morally . Therefore, the predictions of science are not relevant to our moral duty to be morally concerned .

 Kaolin-producing states include Georgia, South Carolina, Pennsylvania, Florida, North Carolina, and North Carolina . Kaolin is produced in the United States .
 Kaolin is either mined dry with a shovel, or dislodged with jets of water and sucked into a pump system . Kaolin can be mined dry by shovels, or by water jets to dislodge the material .
 It is washed, washed and put through separation processes to remove sand, mica, and iron-oxide impurities . Then it is washed .
 Excess water is then removed, and the clay is formed into cakes that are dried and shipped to potteries . Excesses of water are then removed from the clay, and then removed .
 Kaolin is also used in textiles, as a coating for paper, and as a filler for rubber tires . Kaolin also used as a filler for tires and in coating for textiles .
 Kapok, KAY pahk or KAP uhk, is a light, soft, lustrous, cottonlike fiber . Kapok is light and lustrous cotton like cotton .
 Kapok trees grow in Indonesia, the Philippines, India, Sri Lanka, tropical America, and Africa . Kapok Trees grow in tropical America and tropical America .
 After the ripe fruit of the kapok tree is picked, the seeds and fibers are taken out and dried in the sun . After the fruit is ripe, it is taken out of the tree and dried to dry in sun .
 Workers separate seeds and fibers and pack the fibers into bales . Workers then separate the seeds from fibers and then pack them into a bale .
 It is useful as a filling for mattresses and furniture, and also as a substitute for cork in life jackets .
 In many of these uses, kapok is being replaced by synthetic fibers, which cost less and are more durable . Synthetic fibers are being replaced with cheaper, more durable fibers . In many cases, the fibers cost less, and are used in many of the world's most popular
 The kapok, or silk-cotton, tree belongs to the bombax family, Bombacaceae . Kapok is a silk-covered silk-cloth tree .

 Most blows aimed at body parts that are easily injured, such as the stomach and throat . Most blows are aimed at those areas where the body parts are easily hurt .
 There are four major types of karate, including Chinese, Japanese, Korean, and Okinawan .
 All use the same basic techniques, but each stresses certain skills and has its own characteristic style of movement .
 Chinese karate, called kung fu, also spelled gongfu, uses a flowing, circular motion that differs from hard, powerful movements of the other types .

 Students and teachers wear a uniform called a g/ that consists of a loose cotton jacket tied with a colored belt, and pants with a drawstring or elastic waist . A g/ is a uniform worn by students and teachers .
 The students begin by doing exercises to strengthen and stretch their muscles . The students use exercises to stretch and strengthen muscles .
 Students practice punching bags, imaginary opponents, and each other . Students practice with punching bags and imaginary opponents .
 When working with each other, they either stop short of hitting or touch their opponent only lightly . The pair touch their opponents lightly or lightly .

 Students earn promotions by demonstrating to a licensed examiner or a group of licensed examiners the techniques required for the next rank . Students can be promoted to a higher rank by demonstrating their skills to the next level .

 They teach that the conditions of a person’s life result from his or her karma in previous lives . They say that they teach people that karma in their previous lives can affect their life .

 They relied on their herds of sheep, camels, cattle, and horses for food, clothing, and transportation . They relied heavily on livestock for food and clothing .

 William R Childs Kellogg-Briand Pact, also called the Pact of Paris, condemned the use of war to solve international problems and called for peaceful settlement of disputes . The Pact was signed by Childs Childs, the son of William Childs .
 French Foreign Minister Aristide Briand originally proposed the pact in 1927 as a treaty between France and the U.S. The pact was originally proposed by the French foreign minister . It was originally intended to be a treaty with the United States .
 Frank B Kellogg, the United States secretary of state, enlarged the plan in 1928 to include all nations . The plan was enlarged to include nations in 1928 .
 The signers included all the nations in the world except Argentina, Bolivia, E] Salvador, Uruguay, and Uruguay . Andorra, Liechtenstein, Monaco, and San Marino also signed .
 Japan claimed this right in the 1930's, when it fought against China without formally declaring war . Japan claimed the right to claim the right in 1930's .
 The pact provided no way to enforce its provisions . It could not prevent attacks, such as the one Italy launched against Ethiopia in 1935 .
 Although the pact has been violated many times, it has never officially been canceled . The pact has never been officially canceled .
 After World War I! , the Allies used the pact against individuals, rather than against nations . The pact was used to protect individuals, not nations, during the war .
 The pact became part of the legal basis for the Nuremberg and Tokyo war crimes trials . The pact was part of a legal basis of the Nuresmberg and the Tokyo trials . It was used as a basis for both the trials of the two World War II leaders .

 They usually are raised above the surface of the skin and extend beyond the original skin injury . The scars are usually raised above surface of skin and extended beyond original injury .

 Kelp is any of a variety of large, brown to brownishgreen seaweeds that grow underwater and on rocky shores . Kelp can be found in the UK and Australia .
 One type of kelp may have hundreds of branches, each of which has hundreds of leaves . Giant kelp, called giant kelp , may have branches of which each have hundreds leaves .
 In areas where many giant kelps live together, they form underwater forests . In areas of underwater forests, they often live together together .
 Some species consist of a single branch and grow less than 3 feet long . Some species of tree branches consist of just one branch . Others consist of only one branch of a tree .
 Kelps have a complex type of life cycle known as a/ternation of generations . Kelps live in a complex life cycle called a complex form of life .
 Other animals, including lobsters and many fish, use kelps for shelter . Many animals, such as lobsters, use them for shelter.
 People in China and Japan grow kelp for food on special farms in the ocean . The kelp is grown in special farms on the ocean floor in Japan .
 In the United States and many other countries, kelps are collected from the places where they grow naturally . In the U.S. and many others countries, they collect them from the place they grow .
 Harvested kelps yield a/gin, a substance used in the manufacture of ice cream, salad dressing, beer, paper, cosmetics, and other products .

 In 1900, an assassin’s bullet killed the governor of Kentucky, William Goebel, and Kentucky nearly had a civil war of its own . The governor was killed by an assassin's bullet .
 From 1904 to 1909, Kentucky farmers fought a group of tobacco firms in the so-called Tobacco Wars . From 1904-1909, the Tobacco Wars was a series of battles between Kentucky farmers and tobacco firms .
 Kentucky got its name from a Cherokee Indian word whose possible meanings include Land of Tomorrow and Meadow/land . Kentucky was named from the word "Kentucky" Kentucky is Kentucky's largest state .
 Kentucky was named a commonwealth to honor Virginia, which owned the region before Kentucky became a state . The state was named after the region, which was owned by Virginia .

 The first Derby was run in 1875 as part of the program for the opening of Churchill Downs race track in Louisville . The first race was held at Churchill Downs in Louisville, Kentucky . The Derby is the longest horse race in the history of the Derby .

 Kentucky's largest cities, most of its horse farms, and much of its manufacturing are in the Bluegrass Region . The Bluegrass region is home to the state's largest city and most of the horse farms .
 Along the eastern, southern, and western edges of the Bluegrass Region lies an arc of conelike sandstone knobs interlaced by stream flood plains . The Bluegrass region is known for its sandstone and sandstone formations .
 The Pennyroyal Region stretches along Kentucky's southern border from the Appalachian Plateau to Kentucky Lake . The Mississippi Plateau is also known as the Kentucky Plateau .
 The Pennyroyal Region is named for a small herb of the mint family that is common in the region . The region was named for the small herb that is commonly found in the area .
 The southern part of the region has flat and rolling farmland with limestone soils . It has flat farmland and limestone soils in the southern part .

 The Western Coal Field is a region of sharply rolling land in northwestern Kentucky . The region is known for its sharply rolling terrain .
 The region is surrounded by the Ohio River on the north, and by the Pennyroyal Region on the east, south, and west . The area is also surrounded by a network of rivers and streams .
 The Jackson Purchase Region is part of the East Gulf Coastal Plain, which extends from Florida west to Mississippi and north to Illinois . The region is located in the Jackson Purchase region .
 The region is bordered by Kentucky Lake on the east, the Ohio River on the north, and the Mississippi River in the west . The region has a population of 4 million people .
 A double bend in the Mississippi River separates about 10 square miles of extreme southwestern Kentucky from the rest of the state . The area is part of a UNESCO World Heritage Institute .

 In 1815, the steamboat Enterprise traveled from New Orleans to Louisville . The Enterprise was the first steamboat to travel to Louisville, Kentucky .
 It was the first steamboat to travel up the Mississippi and Ohio rivers . It was also the first to travel on the Ohio and Mississippi .
 Steamboats were regularly carrying passengers and cargo along both rivers . Soon, steamboats began carrying passengers along the rivers .
 Kentucky's first railroad, the Lexington and Ohio, began operating in 1832 . It was the first railroad in Kentucky to open a railroad .
 It later became a part of the Louisville and Nashville Railroad, and it is now part of CSX Railroad . CSX is now the largest railroad in North America .
 In 1914, the legislature approved a system of free roads throughout the state . The state legislature approved the system in 1914 . Today, the state's roads are free .
 The Mississippi River, which forms Kentucky's western border, links the state with the Gulf of Mexico . Kentucky is one of the most populous states in the world .
 Many barges travel to and from the Mississippi River on the Ohio River, which forms Kentucky's northern border . The Ohio River is the source of many of Kentucky's rivers .

 The state's busiest airport is the Cincinnati/Northern Kentucky International Airport . The Cincinnati airport is located in Boone County, near the Ohio border .

 Constitutional amendments may be proposed by the state legislature or by a constitutional convention . Constitutional amendments are proposed by state legislatures or by constitutional convention delegates .
 An amendment must be approved by threefifths of the members of each house . An amendment to the bill must be agreed by three-fifths in each chamber .
 The amendment must then be approved in a general election by a majority of the people voting on the issue . The amendment then needs to be approved by a larger majority of voters in the country .
 Before a constitutional convention can meet, it must be approved by a majority of each house of the legislature . A constitutional convention must be held in the U.S. before it meets .
 A constitutional convention must be approved by a majority of the people voting on the proposition . A majority of those voting on a convention must also approve of a constitutional convention . The convention would be held in New Mexico .
 The number of approving votes must equal at least a fourth of the number of voters who took part in the most recent general election . Approval votes must be equal to at least one in four of the voters who voted for the government .

 The number of circuit court judges in a circuit depends on the circuit's population . A circuit's number of judges is based on the population of the circuit .
 The court system includes 59 district courts, which are also used as trial courts . The district courts are used as district courts and trial courts.

 Kentucky Lake is an artificially created lake in western Kentucky and Tennessee . Kentucky Lake was created in 1953 . It is located in Kentucky, Tennessee and Kentucky .
 Kentucky Dam was formed by the Kentucky Dam, which was built across the Tennessee River . The Kentucky Dam is one of the largest dams in the world .
 The lake can hold more than 6 million acre-feet (7. billion cubic meters) of water . It is the largest Tennessee River reservoir in the country .
 Kentucky Dam lies in Kentucky, about 15 miles (24 kilometers) southeast of Paducah . Kentucky Dam is located near Kentucky's Kentucky Dam .
 The gravity-type concrete dam has a hydroelectric power plant with a 160,000-kilowatt capacity . The dam has been built in the 1960s and 1970s . It is the largest dam in the world .
 The dam also has a lock that permits barges to move up and down the river . The dam is located in the heart of the Mississippi River .

 Carl G Rosberg Kepler, Johannes Kepler, yvoh HAHN uhs, discovered three laws of planetary motion . Kepler was a German astronomer and mathematician . Kepler discovered the laws of planet's motion .
 Every planet follows an oval-shaped path, or orbit, around the sun, called an e/lipse . Every planet orbits the sun around the globe, with an orbit around the planet .
 An imaginary line from the sun to the center of a planet sweeps out the same area in a given time . The imaginary line sweeps out an area in the same time as a planet .
 The time taken by a planet to make one complete trip around the sun is its period . The planet's period is the length of a planet's orbit around the solar system .
 The squares of the periods of two planets are proportional to the cubes of their mean distances from the sun . The squares are proportionate to the cube of the planets' mean distance from each other .
 He left Graz rather than undergo compulsory conversion to Roman Catholicism . Graz was forced to leave Graz to undergo conversion to Catholicism .

 Kepler joined Brahe's observatory in Prague, in what is now the Czech Republic . Kepler was the greatest astronomical observer before the introduction of the telescope .

 Kepler made his most significant discoveries trying to find an orbit to fit all Brahe’s observations of the planet Mars . Kepler's most significant discovery was the discovery of a planet on Mars .
 Earlier astronomers thought a planet's orbit was a circle or a combination of circles . Now astronomers say it's more complicated than a circle and a circle .
 Kepler could not find a circular arrangement to agree with Brahe’s observations . However, Kepler was unable to find the circular arrangement .
 He realized that the orbit could not be circular and resorted to an ellipse in his calculations . He used the figure to calculate an orbit around the globe .

 Keratin, KEHR uh tihn, is a tough, insoluble protein found in the outer layer of the skin of human beings and many other animals . Keratin is found in most of the world's skin and is insoluble .
 The keratin in these cells makes the skin tough and almost completely waterproof . Keratin is the material that makes skin waterproof and tough .
 In places exposed to much rubbing and pressure, the number of cells containing keratin increases and a callus develops . In places where the skin is exposed to a lot of rubbing, such as parts of the hands and feet .
 Cells containing keratin are constantly being shed and replaced by new ones . Cells that contain keratin constantly shed and replace new ones.
 The condition known as dandruff results when the scalp sheds such cells . Dandruff is caused by the scalp shedding such cells such as scalp cells .
 In animals, such growths as horns, hoofs, claws, feathers, and scales consist mainly of keratin . keratin is a protein protein protein found in keratin in many of the animal's growths .
 Keratin helps make these structures stronger and better suited to protect the body from the environment . Keratin is a key ingredient in the body's protection against the environment and helps make it stronger .

 At one time, kerosene lamps were the chief source of artificial lighting . Kerosene lamp lamps were used to light up .

 Weedkillers and insecticides usually contain kerosene with a high aromatic hydrocarbon content . Kerosene is often used in weedkillers, insecticides and other insecticides .
 In kerosene used for lighting, a lower content is desirable because aromatic hydrocarbons provide a poor flame and much smoke . But a lower level of aromatic hydrocarbonbons are desirable because they provide poor flame .
 Refiners then treat kerosene to remove impurities such as sulfur compounds and some aromatic hydrocarbons . Refiners remove sulfur compounds from the kerosine .

 Peter O Muller Keyboard is a set of keys on a typewriter or on an input device used to enter information into a computer . Keyboard keys are keys used on typewriters or input devices used for entering information into computers. Keyboard keys can be used in typewriter, computer or typew
 Most keyboards in English-speaking countries use a layout known as QWERTY . The letters Q WER, T, and Yappear in succession near the upper left-hand corner of the keyboard .
 Christopher Latham Sholes, one of the inventors of the earliest practical typewriter, helped develop this layout . Sholes invented the typewriter's layout in the 1930s .
 Four arrow keys enable the computer user to move an electronic marker called the cursor or insertion point up, down, left, or right on the computer screen . The arrow keys can also be used to move the electronic marker up or down on the screen .
 A few keyboards have a built-in trackball, touch pad, or other device that can be used to control the insertion point . The insertion point can also be controlled by a trackball or touch pad .
 A computer keyboard also has numerical keys grouped in a keypad to help users enter numbers quickly . The keyboard has a group of keys grouped together to make numbers easier to enter quickly .
 A user can hold down such special keys as command, control, or alt, and then press other keys to command the computer in a number of ways . Command, control and alt are commands that can be used to command a computer .
 Computer users can reprogram the keys on many keyboards to produce other characters or perform special functions . Keyboard keys can also be reprogrammed to produce special characters or to perform functions .
 Some keyboards include buttons for adjusting the volume of the computer's speaker . Some keyboards also have buttons for playing audio compact disc or launching programs .
 Most computer keyboards have several status lights that indicate certain conditions . Status lights can be used to indicate conditions in certain areas of the keyboard .
 Caps lock light indicates that as letters are typed they will appear as capital letters . For example, a caps lock light will indicate that letters will be capital letters when typed .
 Many ergonomic computer keyboards have key arrangements that are considered to be better-suited to the human hand than the QWERTY layout . The keyboard layout is designed to be ergonomically suited to humans .
 The keys on ergonomic keyboards are often divided into two or three groups, with each group mounted at a different angle to the bottom of the keyboard . The keys are often mounted at different angles to the keyboard.
 His General Theory of Employment, Interest, and Money is one of the most important books on economics . He also wrote a book on the economy .
 It changed economic theory and policy and laid the foundations of modern theories of macroeconomics . It laid the foundation for modern macroeconomic theories .
 Macroeconomics deals with the economy as a whole, including total production, overall employment, and general price levels . Macroeconomic analysis deals with total production and employment, including employment and production levels .
 Keynes maintained that governments should use fiscal policy to stabilize the economy . Keynes maintains that governments must use fiscal policies to stabilize economy .
 Overall level of economic activity depends on effective demand, economist says . Total spending by individuals, businesses, and government is key to economic growth, he says .
 Keynes said that major depressions occur as a result of a drop in effective demand . Keynes said the Great Depression of the 1930's was caused by a drop of effective demand in the 1930s .
 In periods of depression the government should increase its spending, cut taxes, or do both to stimulate the economy . He argued that in times of depression government should raise spending or cut taxes to stimulate economy .
 On most computer keyboards, the other groupings of keys include function keys along the top row; a number pad at the right; and navigation keys . navigation keys include arrow keys and the Home, End, Page Up, and Page Down keys .
 Special keys along the bottom row, such as Alt and Ctrl, can be held down at the same time as other keys to give those keys extra functions . Special keys include Alt, Ctrl and Alt and Alt keys .

 The Khyber Pass cuts through the Safed Koh mountains, which are part of the Hindu Kush range . It is one of the largest mountain passes in the world .

 Kibbutz, kih BOOTS , is a form of Jewish community in Israel based on the idea of social and economic equality .
 Members of a kibbutz share ownership of all the means of income production, including land and businesses . Members of the kibitzes share ownership .
 In most cases, members employed outside the kibbutz turn over their salaries to the kielz . Members employed outside of the kiez turn their salaries over their kielzeis' behalf .
 The kibbutz is responsible for providing education, health care, and housing to individuals and families . It also provides housing, education and health care .
 Before the 1980's, all kibbutz members worked for the kib butz and received goods and services for their labor instead of wages . Nowadays, the majority of kibButz members are paid for services and goods .
 When kibbutzim were first established, adults and children lived separately . Adults and children were often separated from each other . Some children and adults lived separately in kibzim .
 Children were raised in children’s houses, where they slept, played, and studied . Children were brought to children's houses by their parents .
 Since the 1970's, life has become more family-centered, and children are raised by their parents and live at home . Life has changed dramatically since the 1970s, with children living with their parents .
 In most kibbutzim, the highest authority rests in the general assembly, where each adult member gets one vote . The highest authority is in the General Assembly, with each adult kib butzim member getting a vote .
 In some kibbutzim, a representative body has replaced the general assembly . The general assembly is replaced by a representative council . In some of the world's largest kib butzim communities, the assembly has replaced it .

 The kidneys perform many vital functions, including the production of urine . The two kidneys perform important functions such as producing urine, urine production .
 If the kidneys fail to function, poisons build up in the body, eventually causing death . If the kidney fails to function the body may die .
 The kidneys look like purplish-brown kidney beans and are about the size of an adult's fist . The kidneys are about to be the size size of a fist and look like they're about to grow .
 The right kidney, located under the liver, is a little lower than the left one . The kidney is located in the middle of the liver and under the kidneys .
 These layers are, in order, the cortex on the outside of the organ, the medulla, and the pelvis . The cortex is on the inside of the organs and the inside is the inside .
 In the medulla and cortex, the renal artery branches into increasingly smaller arteries . The renal artery branch branches into smaller arteries in the brain's medulla, cortex and cortex .
 Each of the arteries ends in a blood filtration unit called a nephron . Each of these arteries end up in a filthration unit known as the nephrons .
 Two healthy kidneys contain a total of about Medulla Kidneys . Ureters Urinary bladder Uretha Pelvis Renal vein is a sign of a healthy kidney .
 The urine flows through the ureters into the bladder and eventually leaves the body through the body's urethra .
 In the medulla and cortex, the renal artery divides into increasingly smaller vessels, each of which ends in a filtering unit called a nephron . Each of the smaller vessels ends up in a filter unit called the nephrons .
 Within each nephron, much of the blood’s fluid content filters through the glomerulus into the convoluted tubule . The tubule is the convoluted part of the convoluted portion of the nephrons .
 A nephron consists of a network of tiny blood vessels, the glomerulus, surrounded by Bowman’ capsule, a two-layer membrane that opens into a convoluted tubule . Bowman‘ capsule’ is a capsule that opens up a convoluted tube .
 Pressure forces much of the b/ood plasma (fluid portion of the blood) through the glomerulus and into Bowman's capsule . Pressure forces the plasma (part of the plasma) into the capsule . The capsule contains a capsule containing Bowman's plasma .
 The resulting tubular fluid, which contains water and dissolved chemicals, then passes into the convoluted tubule . The resulting fluid is then filled with water, dissolved chemicals and water and other chemicals .
 The portion of the blood that remains in the glomerulus flows into small vessels called capi/laries, which surround the convoluted tubule . The blood that is left in the tubule flows into the small vessels known as capi laries .
 As the tubular fluid flows through the tubules, substances needed by the body are absorbed by the cells of the tubule wall . The tubules are the cells that allow the passage of the fluid through the walls .
 These substances, which include amino acids, glucose, and about 99 percent of the water, then rejoin the blood in the capillaries . These substances then return to the body in capillsaries .
 The capillaries return the blood to the heart by way of the renal vein . The renal vein is used to return blood from the heart to the inside of the heart .
 Substances not absorbed in the tubule are wastes that the body cannot use . Substances that are not absorbed are waste that cannot be absorbed by the body . The tubule is an area of the body where the body absorbs waste .
 Other wastes are secreted into tubular fluid by the tubular cells of the kidney . The kidney contains a tubular cell, which contains waste from the kidney cells .
 Various substances, which include ammonia, urea, uric acid, and excess water, make up urine . These various substances, including ammonia and urea , make up the chemical mixture .
 The urine passes from the convoluted tubules into larger collecting tubules and then into the pelvis layer of the kidney . Urine passes through the tubules to the collection tubules in the kidney and pelvis layers . The kidney is the largest organ organ in the world .
 A tube called the ureter carries urine from each kidney into the urinary bladder . The tube carries urine into the bladder and carries it to the bladder .
 Urine collects in the bladder until it passes out of the body through another tube, the urethra . Urine is collected in a bladder until the bladder is emptied .
 Healthy kidneys produce from 1 to 2 quarts (0.95 to 1.95 liters) of urine daily . Healthy kidneys also produce from 0.95-1 liters of urine a day .
 The kidneys secrete a hormone called erythropoietin, which controls the production of red blood cells . In addition to producing urine, the kidneys also secrete erythrothroietin .
 If one kidney is lost in an accident or by disease, the other may enlarge and do the work of both . The kidney may be lost in accident or disease .
 If both kidneys are damaged or lost, waste materials accumulate in the body, causing death . But if both kidneys fail, waste material accumulates in body .
 Kidney infection, called pye/onephritis, ranks as the most common kidney disease . Kidney infections are often caused by a kidney infection .
 Pyelonephritis rarely leads to kidney failure . Unless it is complicated by blockage of the urinary tract, pyelonphritis is rarely caused by blockages .
 The kidneys also can be damaged by antibodies produced to fight bacteria or viruses elsewhere in the body . The kidneys can also be damaged if antibodies are produced by antibodies .
 This type of inflammation is called g/omerulonephritis, formerly known as Bright's disease . It is a form of inflammation known as g/OMERULONEphritis . It was formerly Bright's Disease .
 Long-term or severe high blood pressure can seriously damage the kidneys, as can diabetes . The kidneys can also be seriously damaged by long-term high pressure .
 The blocked urine can damage the kidneys by exerting pressure on them, or it may lead to pyelonephritis . Blockage can also lead to kidney problems, such as pyelonphritis.
 Kidney disorders may also result from birth defects, injuries, or poisoning, or as a side effect of certain medications . Kidney diseases may also end up as a result of birth defects or poisoning .
 Many people who have lost their kidneys or have suffered kidney damage are kept alive by a dialysis machine . Many people in the U.S. need dialysis to survive .
 Patients generally undergo this process, Called hemodialysis, for several hours, three times a week . Patients generally have to undergo this procedure several hours a day .
 Some kidney patients can use ambulatory dialysis, a continuous procedure that does not involve being connected to a machine . The procedure is a continuous process that doesn't involve a dialysis machine .
 In this process, a container of dialysis solution is emptied into the patient's abdominal cavity through a permanently implanted tube . The tube is permanently implanted in the abdomen .
 The solution remains there for several hours, picking up wastes from the bloodstream . The solution picks up the waste from the blood and picks it up from the body .
 The patient then drains the used solution and replaces it with a fresh supply . The patient is then given a new supply .
 Other kidney patients have their diseased kidneys replaced with healthy ones in a kidney transplant . Other patients in the transplant have healthy kidneys replaced by healthy ones .
 A replacement organ from a close relative is desirable because it closely matches the patient's tissues . The organ is a close family member's organ . It is desirable to replace organ from close relatives with a new organ .
 Most replacement organs come from unrelated individuals who have died in accidents or from other causes . But most replacement organs are taken from unrelated people who die in accidents .
 Modern medicines are usually able to control the rejection process and protect the transplanted kidney . Modern medicines can also be used to protect the transplant .
 Kidney stone is a hard object that forms in the kidneys . Bladder Nephritis Elimination Transplant Gout Urea Human body Uremia Kidney Stone Urine Kidney stones .
 Kidney stones range in size from microscopic to about as large as a golf ball . Kidney stone stones range between microscopic and large as golf ball size .
 They occur primarily in men and can cause intense pain if they become stuck in the urinary tract . They are caused by men who become trapped in the bladder . They can cause severe pain in the abdomen if they are stuck in a urinary tract.
 Some people who develop kidney stones absorb an unusually high amount of calcium from their diet . Some people absorb a lot of the calcium from a diet that can cause kidney stones .

 These movements include gestures, facial expressions, eye behavior, and posture . These movements can be used to communicate with others .
 The movements studied by kinesic scientists are commonly called body /anguage or nonverbal behavior . The movements are commonly known as body /language or non-verbal behavior.
 Kinesics was developed by the American anthropologist Ray L Birdwhistell . It was developed in the 1960s by an anthropologist .

 Kirlian photography, K/HR /ee uh, is the process of creating an image of an object by exposing it to an electromagnetic field .
 Images may be captured with ordinary photographic methods or by more sophisticated techniques . The images may be taken with ordinary photography methods or with more advanced techniques .
 Some scientists once suggested that the images seen in Kirlian photographs resulted from the aura or bioplasma, a theoretical energy field said to surround living things . The aura is said to have been created by an energy field .
 A Kirlian photograph shows discharges of light surrounding an object in this photograph of a human hand . The discharges appear as white and purple bands of light frees and accelerates electrons and positive ions from the object .
 The charged particles collide with neutral molecules and atoms, creating more electrons and ions . The charged particle collision creates more electrons, ions and electrons .
 The electrons and ions recombine and emit red, violet, and ultraviolet light . After a sufficient amount of positive ions has built up, the electrons and iones recombine .
 Kirlian photography can be used to monitor changes in the ions in living tissue . It can also be used in the study of living tissue in the body .
 Some scientists believe that such changes indicate physical or psychological changes in the organism . Scientists believe such changes can indicate physical and psychological changes .
 Researchers also have used Kirlian techniques to detect and measure damaged regions in solid materials .
 Many factors may affect the quality of a Kirlian image, such as the temperature and moisture of the object and the surrounding gas .

 For example, they made fringed skirts, hats, and moccins from tule and animal skins . They also made moccasins, skirts and hats from animal skin .
 The Klamath built two types of houses, one for winter and one for summer . One of the houses was for winter, the other was for summer, the others for the summer .
 For winter, they constructed an earthen lodge by digging a pit in the ground . The lodge was dug for winter in a pit dug by the team .
 They then built walls and a roof of wood and covered them with layers of earth and tule mats . They then laid out walls and roofed them with tule mat mats and earth layers .
 An opening in the roof served as both an entrance and a hole to let out smoke . It was used as a place to let smoke out of the roof .
 For summer, the Klamath built a shelter called a wickiup . It consisted of a willow frame covered with tule mats . The shelter was built from willow frames .
 They also built small sweat /odges, where they took ceremonial steam baths to purify themselves . The group also built sweat and sweat baths .
